reviews.review_title: A mellow, mesmerizing look at mid-America.
reviews.content: This movie rolls gently along like an early season baseball game or a lazy Sunday afternoon, as the lead character Alvin Straight rolls along the rural highways of Iowa in his lawn tractor.  The movie provides gentle insight into many issues about aging in Midwestern America as it follows Alvin on his quest to visit his dying brother.  This G-Rated flick is a gem.

If I like Lynch it's because every now and then he makes a movie that's either highly creepy and Lynch-ish, but in a good way (say "Lost Highway) or because he has talent for making the most touching and heart-breaking movies ever ("The Elephant Man"). "The Straight Story" belongs to the second category as it's a very moving story. Although very slow at first and although never actually any faster, the movie grabbed me because Lynch simply found a way to make it interesting. Alvin Straight becomes more and more deep a character as the movie unwinds and as it does so do the teary eyes. This script is marvelous if you want to simply feel the movie and the characters, and Richard Farnsworth, somebody I knew nothing about prior to watching the movie, seems like he's been doing these kind of pictures for years. He just shines, period. The ending was a little confusing at first, but now somehow it just makes sense. The bundle had to be repaired, that's all. Simple, straight, life enriching. 8/10

reviews.review_title: A decent film with a decent lead
reviews.content: The Straight Story is quite a departure for David Lynch; a man who has made a name for himself for his strange and surreal movies. It is, however, an unwelcome departure as although this movie isn't bad, it's hardly up to the high standard that we're used to from a man that has brought us such classics as 'The Elephant Man' and 'Blue Velvet'. The movie follows the story of Archie Straight; a man that doesn't have a drivers licence, doesn't like other people driving and has a sick brother that lives a long way away. So, he decides that he'll make the journey, on his lawn mower. Sounds boring? You bet, but it's not actually as boring as it could have been. Richard Farnsworth stars in the lead role, and is believable as the old man that wants to see his brother, but it's hard to say that his performance is good - simply because it doesn't require any talent to play. Archie is a typical old man, and since Farnsworth is also an old man; it's simply an old man playing an old man. The rest of the cast isn't really in it enough to make a fair judgment on, and the only other real star is Sissy Spacek. Spacek has proved that she can act with films like Carrie and In The Bedroom, but if you had only seen her here, you'd be forgiven for thinking that she couldn't. She spends the film talking. very. slowly. like. this. and although, obviously, the character needed to be played like that since it's based on a true story, it's hard to call her performance 'good'.The Straight Story is very similar in nature to classic Bergman film; Wild Strawberries, in that it's about an old man taking a road trip, and coming to terms with his age and giving advice to younger people. This idea of getting old was also explored to an extremely high standard in 2002's underground hit - Bubba Ho-Tep. Here, however, the message is lost under masses and masses of fake sentimentality, of which the movie is soaked in. It simply doesn't always work, and Lynch would have been much better served by laying off the sentiment and packing in the more important things - like story. That being said, the movie does have its moments where the sentiment does work and these moments are definitely good; but they're few and far between. There is also some important life lessons in the movie, but like the sentiment; it's few and far between. The movie also uses a fade to black editing technique, which gets irritating very quickly.Overall, The Straight Story is a decent film with a decent lead performance; but that's all. Despite the fact that it's not bad, I would have a hard time recommending the movie to anyone. Although it has it's moments, there simply isn't enough of them and that makes it hard to recommend, and therefore hard to recommend not watching either Wild Strawberries or Bubba Ho-Tep instead. So yes, if I was you; I'd see one of those two movies and leave this one.

reviews.review_title: An old man decides to visit his brother whom he hasn't seen in years, and he does it by traveling very slowly.
reviews.content: Not in much of a rush, was he? He must really like his brother. A lot.This is such a yawn of a film! The first half is even watchable enough and can be survived without permanent brain damage if one has the necessary mental discipline, but the second half - and particularly the last half-hour - are so S L O W that I can't see how anyone can consider this to be anything else but a forgettable mediocrity. But because Lynch made it the film predictably gets overpraised, as is the case with most of his post-"Elephant Man" movies. (It's so very easy for critics to rate this yawner highly when they don't have to sit through it; they simply know who directed it and immediately have an opinion.) Lynch basically directs the camera at the main character but nothing happens. If he'd even picked his nose once it'd have been an event! This lack of activity is in the vast majority of the scenes, while soppy, cliché Hollywood music doodles in the background - and this pathetic and highly unoriginal combination of sad-old-man and soppy-little-ditties is supposed to make the viewer fall into uncontrollable weeping frenzies. The ending is particularly pathetic. This movie is a sleeping pill the size of Arizona.This isn't even a chick flick: it's a pensioners flick.

David Lynch is famous for such movies as Blue Velvet and of course his student film Eraser head. I don't mind Lynch's work but I often find him a little bit too obvious when it comes to the emotional content of his work.Despite his love of making movies that leave most people completely baffled and loving it he decided to make a movie based on a simple true story of a man who travels by ride on lawn mower to visit his brother.That fact alone is all the surreality this movies needs. The pace is as slow as both the tractor and Alvin Straight, but this pacing is perfect. Funny, touching and both ordinary and different at the same time. A nice movie to watch on a lazy rainy Sunday afternoon.One of the funny stories is that many older people enjoyed this movie so much that they decided to see David Lynch's next effort, Mulholland Drive.....many also left by the time of the first lesbian love scene of that movie.

I saw this quite some time ago but was thinking about it all day today for some reason. It is a wonderful heartwarming film about one man's journey back through his life stopping at key points along the way. I felt that the character almost had some higher power guiding him. For example in the scene when all the cyclists fly past him in their droves he chugs along at his usual pace. Then later he looks up and sees a storm coming and he is in the middle of nowhere. No shelter anywhere. Then he glances over and sees a small barn. Heading towards it he parks inside at the moment the Heavens open. Safe and protected from the force of nature. It is such a simple moment but is executed so well. The pace of the film is wonderful and quite frankly I could watch Farnsworth for hours as he has that kind of face. Lynch has found the perfect balance for his story here and made a solid memorable film.

reviews.review_title: If you have not seen this film? NOW WOULD BE THE PERFECT TIME!
reviews.content: This was quite simply a marvel of a film in every way.  It, to me, personified and illustrated perfectly Spencer Tracey's quote "Acting is alright, just don't let anybody catch you doing it"  Sissy, and Farnsworth were not caught.  There performances were subtle, powerful and beautiful. In a word! Brilliant!...  What is more, BELIEVE ABLE...never once did I doubt them or lose touch with their characters.  Sissy Spacek was totally overlooked by the Academy...she is I believe along with Holly Hunter, Judi Dench & Joan Plowright probably the greatest actress alive.  I have never been a big fan of David Lynch, but what ever his detractors might say about him , he cannot be convicted of not knowing how to portray people sensitively, one must just look at Elephant Man to know he does "sensitive" and "personal" with the best of them.  He certainly did that here.  I also liked in this film a little nuance of his, that when the camera was a few yards away from the subject the sound went down....forcing one to listen carefully to the dialog....much like it would be if you were actually standing 30 or 40 feet from someone trying to hear what they were saying. I have long ago lost faith in the Academy, but It should be criminally prosecutable to have compared the acting in this film, that is to say, the acting of Farnsworth with that of Kevin Spacey in American Beauty.  Those who awarded and voted for Kevin should be sentenced to the chain Gang, Long Sentences with water and dried bread.  THIS FILM SHOULD BE  A 10 on anyones story board.  And an 11 in the heart.  Oh Yes, and I have never seen a better ending  to a film like this...nor a better choice as the leads brother than Harry Dean Stanton. David Lynch proves and sees with a clear eye that "less is more" it is a magnificent Ending....Perfect....Flawless BEAUTIFUL! Hey! It just dawned on me.....Perhaps I am a David Lycnh Fan Afterall? ?

reviews.review_title: The Straight Story really struck a chord in me
reviews.content: Went in expecting something like, I dunno, movies I never go see, but I'm delighted to report that not only is this delightful and heartwarming in the best Hollywood tradition, but also unmistakably Lynchian in ways big and small. In some ways, it might actually be the key to unlocking huge swaths of his other work, since it reveals that his affection for small-town communities and the people in them as anything but ironic.

reviews.review_title: An Atmospheric Road-Movie about Endurance and Triumph over Obstacles
reviews.content: David Lynch is commonly known for making surreal, twisted and ill-minded pictures in which reality often appears as a frightening place. The story usually begins regularly but then, out of the blue, gets nightmare-like elements of disgust and anxiety. However, The Straight Story is a whole new ballgame. It's the opposite to everything Lynch has ever made but still, paradoxically, attains to keep his unique cinematic style together. As an unusual Lynch film, The Straight Story is a slow and tender road-movie about an old man who decides to travel a long journey by a lawn mower to see an ill brother of his. At its heart, the film is a straight story about real life, which might still exist somewhere; life where people are nice to each other and don't only think of their own benefit; life where solidarity is no longer vanishing folklore. Due to this, the film even seems quite mythological -- for better and worse. Moreover, the film highlights the importance of family, friends and love, as well as wisdom and righteousness. To some, all this might sound a bit foolish and artificially cheery but, conversely, a director like Lynch achieves to create an actual presence of calm rest. The monotonous procrastination of the events is only there to tame the wildest viewer of modern hectic cinema. Even as being a total exception in Lynch's production, this atmospheric road-movie does still have many typical elements for the director too. Such as the significance of sounds and visuals; even at their most hypnotic. Furthermore, the emotional poetry of the film associates it with The Elephant Man (1980). Besides, and most importantly, there still is the Lynchian absurdity; only this time, it can be seen in the hectic hurry inside and the irrationality of modern life. Although The Straight Story doesn't reach on the level of Lynch's masterworks, it is, nonetheless, touching in all its authenticity and modest sincerity. At times, its sentimentality leads to idealistic interpretation but, however the old man's stubbornness, and the honesty of the story, balance it. In conclusion, The Straight Story tells about life with its ups and downs. Beneath the surface one doesn't find horror, as usual, but beauty. On the other hand, the story about an absurd adventure on a lawn mower -- through the South regions -- can also be seen as an ironic comment on the concept of mythical America. In any case, and above all, The Straight Story is a meditative and highly personal journey into the clarity of what is important in life.

reviews.review_title: Worth the $26.50 it took to get my whole family to the movies
reviews.content: This is one of the first movies of the year my whole family has gone to see. My mother (who should have a "kill your local cinema" bumper sticker) even liked it. I thought it started out in a mocking manner but eventually arrived at pure truth and sweetness. It painted a very human picture of the world, and that should be admired in a film these days. Plus it contains one of the most interesting cinematic vinettes ever involving a woman and her "car trouble." Pure magic.

There have been countless road trip movies made over the years, some were great, a lot were not so great. This 1999 road trip movie is based on a true story... the story of an old man's determination to visit his sick brother. The problem is he cannot drive a car, so, he elects to take the trip driving a John Deer ride on mower. Given that premise. it could be mistaken for a comedy scenario, but it is definitely not. It is a warm and touching story that hold your interest for the entire journey. The great Richard Farnsworth plays Alvin Straight and his character portrayal is excellent. The people he encounters along the way and the awesome scenery make this movie work. The acting is natural and believable. Notable cast members include Sissy Spacek as Rose Straight (Alvin's daughter) and Harry Dean Stanton as Lyle (Alvin's brother). Although their roles are small, they shine as their characters. I have watched this movie several times.... it just works for me. There is nothing to dislike and there are a lot of life lessons to be learned from watching it. Sadly. this was to be Richard Farnsworth's final movie.. he couldn't have finished on a finer note.

This is one of those over-rated films that has you scratching yourhead with regard to the accolades heaped on it.  I guess if you goto Hollywood movies, it may seem like a nice respite to seeMid-America on the big screen.  However, if you're a film buff, you'llfind the story thin and the acting weak. The opening scene is very strong & interesting. Sissy Spacek isthe only thing that redeems this film, however Lynch ditches hercharacter once the central character undertakes his journey(another short coming of the film).  As the main characterundertakes his journey we see numerous shots of amber wavesof grain while Badalameti's score is playing (yawn). All thecharacters we meet along the way are over-acted, particularly thesmarmy  couple he stays with.  Harry Dean Stanton does a ratherpoor job as the brother & the dialogue between the 2 is completelyphoney.

One of my most favorite movies ever. I am European and it is nice for once to see a movie which portraits the real America. Not the America of the shallow rich and famous but the America of the ordinary people with a heart and soul. It is also full of pure poetry and wisdom. Haven't we all once sheltered from the rain, smelled the fragrance of the wet dirt at least once in our childhood, just like Alvin does in the open fields?This movie also holds the fundamental rhythms of life. A masterpiece recommended to all.

This is a great film, full of subtle humor and never condescending or snide as some have depicted the Great Plains ('Fargo' et al).  Watched it on video and was never tempted to hit the fast forward in even the slowest moments; they didn't FEEL slow.  Unbelievable:  don't miss it!

reviews.review_title: mr lynch has created another sublime film
reviews.content: straight story, straight from the heart, emotion not sentiment, a slow sedate but complettly involving film with all round brilliant perfomances. and so many moments of sublime beauty and uplifting spiritual emotion. badalameti creates another exquisite score, like all the elements in the film understated yet powerful.  this film is up there with shawsank and almost reaches the heights of lynch's own elephant man

I went into this movie thinking that it was gonna have the usual lynch stench that most of his movies have. However, I was pleasantly surprised to find out that the straight story did not. This was a simple story that was told beautifully with some wonderful background music. Alvin, who is on the verge of a stroke himself, is told the news that his brother, who he has not talked to for years, had a stroke. With no way of getting to his brothers, Alvin decides to drive his lawn mower across 2 states to get to his brother.  Along the way, Alvin runs into some people who he without a doubt changes their outlook on life forever with his simple words of wisdom. You will be touched by this movie and fall in love with the main character.

David Lynch's simplest masterpiece. Blowing away from his eccentric, eerie plays he puts down a story that I may truly call "crystal clear". The feelings are intensely pure, the air seems calm and the road peaceful. This movie is a revitalizing experience, mainly based on the Oscar worth acting by John Fainsworth and his travel to visit his brother; on a tractor. Although it seems childish, he doesn't have any rush.He will not be delayed, he won't have problems. He has time, he has will. He has his own and he can enjoy life in it's sunset. He is truly calm. Do you need any more?

reviews.review_title: Very not mainstream despite the 'straight' storyline.
reviews.content: [No Spoilers]Being a David Lynch film, one could have the idea that it depicts that enigmatic mind of his like the majority of his feature films do. But it is a very straight story as the title might hint. Don't except to be caught in the usual Lynchian void of incomprehensibility that usually occurs after viewing i.e. Lost Highway. It is a simple film but it is indeed a great film. That is both from a innovative and an entertaining aspect. It's innovative because it so not Lynch. But maybe that IS Lynch. He likes to twist our minds and therefore puts together a film that might seem very mainstream and far from Lynch himself. Being a very avantgarde director, he might just make a film like this just to tease his regular audience because he knows what they expect but he doesn't give it to them. That would be crafty.The pace of the film is slow. I would almost say lawn mower speed... Don't expect an action orgy, but the film is truly entertaining for the ones who go with the flow of the film.  Look carefully for those small details that Lynch plot throughout the movie for our entertainment. Look for the great cinematography that makes this film come to life. And listen to Badalamenti's score and the main theme that really animates the Iowa and Wisconsin landscapes shown frequently. Farnsworth puts in one of his best performances in this film, making him one of the most likeable ol' men ever depicted on film. He doesn't have to say anything to express his feelings and thoughts. His cheerfulness just shines right through him and his acting earned him an Oscar nomination. Need I say that his weak health in this film wasn't acted? He was diagnosed with cancer and shot himself right after this film was complete. That knowledge just puts more emphasis on the film because it becomes more of a homage to Farnsworth. All of the above form a very nice motion picture that is suitable for all kinds of people that like a film the way they are supposed to be done. One could ask for homilies that aren't that obvious and a bit naive but it doesn't ruin the overall picture, being that it is a memorable motion picture. 9/10.

This film was so good I wiped half the video tapes I had recorded from the television the same week because I knew they would appear worthless next to such a masterpiece.The acting, the story and the beautiful camera work all contributed to this most touching of stories. A painting of a landscape with just the right touches of characterful colour in it, with enough reality to make the picture recognisable as a place we know, or that we would like to know.Anyone who does not appreciate this film properly is either too young to have drawn breath from the usual menu of violence and over-mannered "acting" or they live life entirely on the surface.

reviews.review_title: Is this the most boring film of all-time?
reviews.content: "The Straight Story" (1999), I've seen a lot of boring movies in my life. But, this one has found a place on my top five most boring films list! Yes, I do think that it's that bad. Don't get me wrong, I love simple movies well-told. In fact, that's one of the golden rules in cinema, in my opinion, keeping it simple. However, "The Straight Story" is way too simple. This "movie" has a very dull and boring storyline, standard to terrible acting, and a predictable cliched soundtrack. The plot is, a man rides a lawnmower across the country to visit his sick and dying brother. Oops, I just spoiled the "film"! No, really, that's the whole "movie". All right, let me just say this right off the bat. The idea of going through such an extremely monotonous task just to visit a family member is a very charming gesture. But, the story needed more than that to have some resemblance of an impact. Even though he does reach his brother, the payoff is not as satisfying as it should've been. The whole "film" began with nothing and ended with nothing. It's almost on the level of being as bad as "Diner" (1982)! Which is another "movie" where nothing happens. The only somewhat decent part of this "film" is the opening. That was the only part of the "movie" where I actually felt some resemblance of emotion. I thought: "okay, if it keeps up this tension throughout, then it could work!" But no, once he begins his journey, it all goes downhill really fast. Kind of like someone dumped a bucket of water off the top of a cliff. That's how fast the "film" goes downhill! As I mentioned, at least 80% of this "movie" is just a boring man riding a boring lawnmower on a road. They couldn't have shown any dangers or obstacles along the way? If they made the trip more difficult, then maybe it would have had a purpose! Believe it or not, this "film" is based on a true story. What kind of person in their right mind thought this concept would be entertaining? I'll tell you one thing, they must have very low standards for what they watch. I wouldn't green light a boring plot like this! There are so many interesting true stories out there, and this one somehow got made into a movie? Why?! As far as the acting goes, it's overall just as big a letdown as the story. The only passable performances come from the side characters. Some of the main cast do try. But, all of them are just mediocre with their performances. Even Richard Farnsworth, who plays the main character, Alvin Straight, couldn't save this "film". You can just see the boredom on his face whenever he's shown on the screen. Whenever you can tell that an actor or actress is bored, then you know it's a serious problem. The whole time, our main character looks bored out of his mind, which inevitably results in the audience being bored. Finally, the soundtrack composed by Angelo Badalamenti is overall a predictable and cliched mess. There are some good parts, but overall, the film score just sounds like it was rushed together at the last second. When you notice the edits, then you know something is wrong. In this case, Angelo Badalamenti's name should really be Angelo Bad! Now for the good elements in this "movie". Yes, there are actually a couple of redeeming qualities here in this "film". The only good things are the sets/locations and the special effects. All of the sets/locations are great and give this "movie" a decent atmosphere. You cannot go wrong with the midwest! The other good thing is the special effects. All of them were well-done and still hold up to this day. Unfortunately, great sets/locations and special effects are no excuses for poor screenwriting and acting. "The Straight Story" is yet just another overrated and boring mess in the world of cinema. It's a shame, because the story really had serious potential to be so much more. David Lynch has directed much better movies than this. What happened here? When I saw that he directed it, I thought: "oh, if he's directing it, then it should be in good hands." But, it just feels like another person had directed it. Honestly, unless you know he's the director, then you would never guess that he directed it. "The Straight Story" is just another jumbled mess of boredom. It's so bad, that I almost considered putting it on my top ten worst movies of all-time list! Another thing I want to say is, I'm sorry that this was Richard Farnsworth's last film. What a terrible movie to end his career with! He has acted well in other movies and shows. What's his excuse here? Here's a tragic story for you. About a year after this "movie" was released, Richard Farnsworth killed himself. Now, the reason he committed suicide was because he had terminal cancer. But I wonder, was it just the disease alone that caused him to kill himself? Maybe "The Straight Story" had something to do with his suicide! Hmmm..... Any way, I'm struggling to rate this "film" 2 out of 5 stars on my personal scale, which equates to 4 out of 10 IMDB stars. Unless you live a life of never-ending excitement and need to watch a boring movie to level everything out, then stay away from this "film"! I'm just glad that I got this review over with and I never have to see this "movie" ever again. Another thing, "professional" critics like this "film", big shock. I don't know what kind of brain disease they have, hopefully it's not contagious! This "movie" just proves that all "professional" critics are suckers for simple boredom. They're all afraid to be honest with their movie reviews, but I'm not. If you watch this "film", you'll just be wasting 112 minutes of your life.

How anyone can be cynical enough to put down this movie is beyond me. Richard Farnsworth had one of the best voices ever to grace the silver screen. The scene where he's sharing a glass of milk with a beer drinking war veteran (like himself) was one of the most moving moments I think I've seen on film. It should be required for anyone who blindly supports war as gung ho revenge. (hint: soldiers return from combat plagued by guilt and trauma that never go away.) Every word Farnsworth speaks is simple and eloquent and he never lets anyone get the best of him.  (Spoiler? I love the part where those 2 lawn mower repairmen twins were trying to swindle him and he turns it all around on them to remind them how important family is.) Truly one of the best American films in years as well as one of Lynch's best efforts, this is also a fine swan song to one of the most flawless natural actors since probably Spencer Tracy. As for one reviewer claiming Alvin's journey made no sense, watch it again and hear how he explains why he's doing it. It's to atone for the way he behaved in the past. All very easy to understand.

reviews.review_title: Best John Deere Commercial Ever Made
reviews.content: An old man (Richard Farnsworth) makes a long journey by tractor to mend his relationship with an ill brother.Let me just say it up front. The worst part of this film is the character played by Sissy Spacek. Maybe we are supposed to feel pity for her stammering, but it was so obnoxious that it brought my enjoyment of the film down a few notches.I had never heard of this story before, and I am quite certain it is embellished, but it is interesting just the same. Would it really take five weeks to get from Iowa to Wisconsin? I would think it would be more like five days. I appreciate that (allegedly) they filmed in the actual locations, too. Not that the area is very interesting, but authenticity is nice. I have driven highway 18 many times and know the territory.There is a running joke in the movie about Wisconsin being a party state. Having lived here thirty years, I will neither confirm nor deny that. I also appreciate the inclusion of a pair called the Olsen Twins.Those used to David Lynch's weirder films (pretty much everything else he has done) may be surprised by how normal this one is. The premise is sort of strange, but the characters are rather mundane. There is no surrealism here, or even a strange lighting, angle or sound. If there is any hint that this is a Lynch film, I missed it. But that does not mean it is not good... just not what fans might expect.

reviews.review_title: The Pope is going to be the next Dalai Lama. :-)
reviews.content: The first second i saw the phrase " a Walt Disney production " at the very begining of this movie i though, " WHAT ?!!" and i got totaly convinced this was going to be a very painfull experience. In fact if i hadn´t bought the DVD, i probably wouldn´t have watched it, and i would ended up missing one of the most beautiful movies i ever made. David Lynch, working for Disney ?! The most politicaly correct movie company ever ?! The only comparison for this must be, if the Pope sudenly got chosen to be the next Dalai Lama !!! :-)Come on, someone must be kidding ! For a second i though i had bought the wrong DVD and i had bought a new Leslie Nielsen comedy instead. Well i couldn´t be more wrong, because this movie is all that i was never expecting it to be. THE STRAIGHT STORY, is one of those very rare movies that can´t be explained, it has to be felt. And so if you will like it or not, will depend mostly upon your view of life and how you feel about your own personal values.By now i´ve already seen this movie about 4 or 5 times since i bought it about a month ago and i can´t get enough of it. Each time i get sad, or tired i just put this one and get carried away by it one more time. Because let me tell you, if you like this movie, every time you start watching it, you just can´t stop untill you´ve finished. Mainly because of Richard Farnsworth. Even today i still have trouble in convincing myself that the Alvin Straight in this movie is "nothing" but an actor playing a character. Richard´s performance is probably the best i ever seen in my life, because we totaly forget that everything in the screen is not real. Simply brilliant. Words can not describe it, once again it´s something that has to be felt.And as if this wasn´t enough, there´s Sissy Spacek, playing one of the most touching and simple characters i ever saw. This woman also deserved a bunch of awards, in fact everyone on this film deserved to go home with plenty of prizes and recognitions. The final minutes with Harry Dean Stanton playing Alvin´s brother are simply breathtaking. Never so many things were said in so few lines of dialogue.If there´s a movie that proves how fake the Oscars are, this is it.Oh,and let´s not forgget about the magnificent soundtrack. Angelo Badalamenti, does a superior work here. Probably his best. This has to be one best soundtracks ever, not because it stays in your mind afterwards, but because it works like magic in the movie. Never intrusive, and totaly beautiful !Go see this movie. And if you think this is another soapy drama, forget it. Emotion here is not flashed right into your eyes all the time. It doesn´t show to yourself, it makes you also feel instead. And this is what makes this movie great. Not what it shows, but what we know is there. Go feel this movie. It´s that good. AMERICAN BEAUTY will be forgotten in time. This movie WON´T.It made me want to buy a lanmower ! When i get old, i want to be like Alvin.

reviews.review_title: GET ON YOUR LAWN MOWER (AND DRIVE)
reviews.content: Poignant and beautiful. That just about sums it up. It's a very good movie, and so un-Lynch like. The photography is excellent, and Farnsworth is superb. He seems to spread sanity in the South on his slow journey. Finally the ending hits just the right note. In a word excellent.

"The Straight Story" is a slow-paced film about a man who travels far to his brother on a lawn mower. Since it's very slow-paced it is certainly not a film for everyone, however, if you take the time to see this film you will see a film where the slow pace is used in a magnificent way (unlike in e.g. the tedious "Il Postino"). Great music, fine cinematography and exceptional acting. (6/10)

The first David Lynch film I saw was The Elephant Man (produced by Mel Brooks) and The Straight Story is quite a touching movie about brotherly love and the desire to make up after a conflict. No special effects here, but a slice of life through America.

reviews.review_title: 73 Year-old Man and His Lawnmower Embark on Final Odyssey!
reviews.content: Richard Farnsworth gives us a wonderful performance as Alvin Straight, who sets off from Iowa to Wisconsin on a John Deere Rider in order to find his brother, Lyle who has suffered a stroke.  Alvin wants to  make amends after nine years.The quiet movie builds on one as Alvin makes his slow way across the Midwest in the months of September and October.  The fertile fields, the down-to-earth, straightforward people, the lovely music all weave a tapestry.  The trip takes on meaning for us as well as for Alvin.  Each person he meets adds a dimension to the tale and become part of it.As the journey draws to a close, we are praying for Alvin and Lyle's reunion.  We know what the meeting will mean to both of them because it has come to mean as much to us.  Great movie!!

I was stunned to see this film listed among the top 120 all-time.  Press and friends raved about the film when released, and when I went to the theatre showing, it was one of perhaps 5 films ever I wish I had left early.  I enjoy character studies, both presented alone as themselves (which I think this film intended), or as adding richness to any genre.  Only 1-2 such scenes are worth viewing for the character/acting quality.  Unfortunately these are interspersed all-too-infrequently across hour after hour of the annoying themesong against an endless backdrop of cornrows.  Even the syrupy-sweet ending is lacking, with painfully short and empty dialogue.

reviews.review_title: Only a fool does not change his mind
reviews.content: I once said I would never watch a David Lynch movie again. That was just after Lost Highway (1997) which I thought was a very irritating movie to watch. I wasn't a big fan of Twin Peaks either, and that while almost everyone I knew were into it. So it's twenty-three years later that I decided to watch The Straight Story, more by accident than by choice to be honest. As soon as I saw his name appear in the begin credits I thought I would be bored out of my mind again but the truth is that this time I did enjoy his movie. Maybe because it's based on a true story, what gives it a special something, but mostly because it's well shot, with great sceneries, very good acting, and a this time interesting and gripping story. Richard Farnsworth did a great job playing his character, he just has the face and presence to play this role. Sissy Spacek was even better, and although her character was lesser present in the movie, the scenes with her were very good. I never thought I would appreciate a movie of David Lynch. Only a fool does not change his mind, it couldn't be more true for this movie.

When David Lynch thinks he has to prove he's a great director, he makes a film like "A Straight Story": an old man traveling 500 miles on a lawn mower! This is indeed a Lynch film, even if a lot of those who thought EWS was slow won't take it. It is also a sort of Zen meditation on old age, death and the beauty of the universe. By the way, why should'nt we take pleasure in slowness? Where is it written that pleasure only comes from fastness? If you find TSS slow (and EWS as well) I guess you are the kind of people who anxiously look at their watch when they make love and think "My God, more than 30 seconds. it's so SLOW!"

The Straight Story is a beautiful, simple movie, a reflection about life and growing old. The story is simple: 73-year-old Alvin Straight makes a 500 km journey in a lawn mower to mend his relationship with his ill brother. During the way, he reflects about growing old, his life and his mistakes. The subtle way this is done is effective and gives the movie beauty, but the story is sometimes too slow, with nothing happening. The dialogs are good, sometimes quotable, even if once or twice I spotted obvious stories that could have been avoided. The characters are all very natural, and you believe them from the first minute you see them on the screen. They are all likable because they are normal people, but always hopeful and with a certain innocence and able to accept life. The ending is, too, very simple but it works extremely well leaving you touched and moved.The acting is very good. Richard Farnsworth gives a wonderful performance. His character, on paper, isn't very interesting, but he's able to give Alvin dramatic nuances. He creates a man that slowly accepts growing old, ignores his pride and goes in a journey to meet his brother. He is stubborn, with a simple but pure morality. He has an amazing delivery of his lines, slowly, realistically, showing his character's controlled emotions in a touching way. Sissy Spacek gives Rosie vulnerability and barely visible pain, never overacting. All the other cast members that make brief appearances do a good, even if not remarkable job, with good delivery of their lines.The direction is brilliant. Lynch fills the movie with gorgeous shots and camera angles, that allow you not only to see the meaning of the screenplay and the great work by the actors', but you can see the beautiful roads and vegetation all around. His shots are steady and reflective just the right style for this movie.The cinematography is very good, capturing the beauty of Lynch's wide shots and the faces in a clear way. The music is beautiful, giving the movie a nostalgic feeling. This is slow moving and sometimes boring; even so, it's technically impressive, beautiful and meaningful.

I am a fan of David Lynch, and obviously was aware that this film was "not very Lynch-y", which is to say that there are no dancing dwarfs, no surreal dialogue, no surreal scenes, it is, as many have already punned, a straight story. However, it is still recognisably a Lynch film  Lynch Unplugged, maybe? It is also a simple story, beautifully told. Everett McGill is the only Lynch regular (that I spotted, anyway  oh, hang on, Harry Dean Stanton gets a couple of seconds) on screen, although the score is recognisably Angelo Badalamenti, and this helped streamline and focus the story, by removing the distractions, actor spotting or references that I usually enjoy in Lynch films.The lack of clutter allows Richard Farnsworth's great performance room to breathe, and while some may find the film too slow (come on  he was on a lawn mower!), I thought that the pacing was spot on and would recommend that, Lynch fan or not, there is something in this film for anyone who has ever taken a long time to admit they've been a fool.

At times slow only because.. well the guy is going pretty slowly through the story.  But otherwise it is very poetic and charming as Farnsworth's twinkle in his eye lights up the screen, and the sweeping prairies is filmed gloriously.Must be something about us prairie people.  I did enjoy the film even though it was a little slow, but I think it had no other choice.Rating 6.5 out of 10

reviews.review_title: A reflective and somber picture with big themes.
reviews.content: David Lynch's "The Straight Story" is undeniably his most compassionate and thoughtful film to date and remains emotionally effective to this day. Additionally, more themes and messages can be drawn with each viewing. The story covers an older Mr. Straight as he makes his way to another state on a lawn mower to see his brother. Performances are authentic and genuine all across the board with some touching moments that feel so emotionally raw for a "G" rated film. While it may be a David Lynch film and his stamp is certainly on it, the story feels straightforward and far from abstract as you might expect. However, that doesn't take away the deeply thought-provoking nature of the film.The story seems to explore old age and one old man's place in a world he has trouble seeing himself again. One who can't do the things he can anymore but wishes maybe certain things were different. We see a man coming to terms with who he is and what choices he's made in his life and while it feels soul searching, it never becomes pretentious or preachy. Lynch and the screenwriters manage to balance realism and emotional interpretation of the character's circumstances. Story and performances aside, "The Straight Story" is technically brilliant and beautifully constructed. Breathtaking landscape shots feel painted with the most saturated of colors while every close-ups capture character's emotion and response in a natural way.This is definitely a slower paced film which might turn the younger audience off. There are times when the pace can drag and become a little inpatient but once someone finishes the film, they'll want to see it again. This is not only a highly recommended (and forgotten) David Lynch film but just a wonderful movie in general.

This is a strange one for David Lynch, more famous for 'weird' movies and TV series: Twin Peaks and such. Richard Farnsworth's final movie with an Oscar nomination, and in which the frailty and beauty of old age, stripped of pretences song ego, is front and centre. The movie is stronger for being based on a true story. The small rural town where Alvin Straight and his mentally handicapped daughter, beautifully played by the wonderful Oscar winner, Sissy Spacek, is down at heel, populated with the old, young people having left. Alvin, too old to legally drive a car, sets out on his ride-on lawnmower to see his estranged brother Lyle who lives in the next state, recently afflicted by a stroke, before the two pass away. Episodes along the way in which he receives the kindness of strangers reveal the fundamental decency of most people. The episode where he communes with a fellow WW2 and D-Day veteran, with hardly a word spoken but the sadness so evident for lost friends, is heartfelt in its subtlety. The credits at the end note that the brothers passed away soon after Alvin's voyage.

David Lynch is one of America's strangest and most compelling directors, but in the 90's his film career was heading in an ugly direction. 1990's Wild at Heart and 1997's Lost Highway both had flashes of off-kilter Lynchian brilliance, but both also seemed rather cruel, soulless and calculated in their weirdness. It would seem that Lynch had lost much of his natural talent for gripping surrealism found in Blue Velvet and Eraserhead, and all of his humanism and compassion found in The Elephant Man. In comes The Straight Story, a shockingly simple and clean breath of fresh air in his career. While many Lynch fans were likely (and understandably) disappointed by the lack of bizarre, dark elements in this gentle, G-rated tale, The Straight Story represents everything I love about Lynch films - his artistry, his eye for oddball details, and his quiet sense of compassion. It also is far more Lynchian than many give it credit for. While there are very few menacing elements here, it still is an evocative, mythic story of a physical and spiritual journey - just played in a far quieter, mellower key than past Lynch efforts.Just about every element of The Straight Story comes together beautifully. Richard Farnsworth is incredible as Alvin Straight, a stubborn old man with years of experience and wisdom etched on his face. The dependably great Sissy Spacek is also wonderful in the unusual, touching role of Alvin's daughter. Angelo Badalamenti's music fits beautifully with the serene images of the Midwest that Alvin slowly crosses on his lawnmower - there are long scenes of nothing but music and scenery that are breathtaking. The Straight Story is, along with The Elephant Man, easily Lynch's most humanistic film. Convincing humanity is found in every corner of this movie - in Alvin's face, in the people he meets who all are carrying their own scars and fears, in the near-wordless but deeply moving final scene. The Straight Story is heartbreaking and tender - an enormously emotional movie that never even verges on melodrama or unearned sentiment. While I do appreciate David Lynch's rare gift for twisted surrealism, I think his gift for expressing deeply-felt emotion is even rarer and more valuable. Films as mature and heartfelt as The Straight Story are few and far between. It quietly snuck up on me and became one of my favorite movies.

reviews.review_title: Full Of Good, Old-Fashioned Advice From Grandfather
reviews.content: If it's action and adventure you want in a movie, then you'd be best advised to look elsewhere. On the other hand, if it's a lazy day and you want a good movie to go along with that mood, check out "The Straight Story."Richard Farnsworth puts on a compelling performance as the gentle and gentlemanly Alvin Straight, in this true story of Alvin's journey on a riding mower across three states to see his estranged brother who has had a stroke.Farnsworth is perfect in this role, as he travels his long and winding road, making friends of strangers and doling out lots of grandfatherly type advice about family along the way. The story moves along as slowly as the riding mower, but somehow manages to keep the viewer watching, waiting for the next life lesson Alvin's going to offer.Stretch out on the couch, relax and enjoy. It's the only way to watch this very good movie, which rates a 7/10 in my book.

reviews.review_title: An interesting cross between an art film and a made-for-TV movie
reviews.content: There were times ,as I watched this movie, where I wasn't sure if I was watching an art house film or a made-for-TV movie; it often sways between the two genres; slow moving, beautifully shot, naturalistic acting and dialogue, but then there are times of real cheese usually supported by the terrible music and several cringing moments of mawkishness and cliched pulling-of-the-heart-strings. However Richard Farnsworth is always worth a watch and he, alone, makes the film worth a look.

reviews.review_title: A straight slice of a disappearing America
reviews.content: 'The Straight Story' is based on the real life tale of the felicitiously named Alvin Stright, portrayed as a somewhat crotchety old man who, wishing to visit his estranged, ailing brother but lacking a driver's licence, travelled 1,000 miles across the corn-belt of America by lawnmover. That's both a long setnece to start this review, but also a fairly full description of the entire film. David Lynch might have been thought of as an unlikely director of such a work; he's always liked to present a mythic version of small-town U. S. A., but normally with a dark underbelly which here is absent. But he gets the tone right, playing it straight (there really is no other way of putting it), and capturing both a grizzled humanity and a vanishing way of life.

reviews.review_title: The worst part of being old is rememberin' when you was young.
reviews.content: With The Straight Story, Lynch demonstrated none of the recognizable trademarks that transformed him into the director that I love. This film felt like a "blind date" gone bad. The Straight Story showed up, David Lynch arrived, but the rest of the date felt muddled, confusing, and utterly disastrous. Everything in this film seemed wrong. Lynch's choice for lead actor, the bland Sissy Spacek, the filler of repeat cornfield montages, all the way to the incoherent time spent on the read, I just felt that nobody had control over this picture, yet the randomness (and the possible tear ending) gave critics something to smile about. This is not a David Lynch film, and for those walking into this with images of Mulholland Drive, Twin Peaks, or even Eraserhead in their mind will be utterly discombobulated. The Straight Story attempted to show us a slice of Americana via the cornfields of Iowa, but for this boy based in the Flatlands of Illinois, it just seemed repetitive and boring.What initially pulled me away from this film was the technique that Lynch used to introduce us to Alvin and his daughter Rose. Alvin lying on the ground because he can't get up, the cliché use of taking him to the doctor letting us know that he is deteriorating, while bringing us the central conflict of his brother falling ill was just too much in such a little time frame. Spacek's depiction of Rose seemed unbalanced and rather stale. She brought nothing fresh to this rather emotional character outside of a stutter and some unfunny scenes. I expected so much more from Spacek with her timeline of cinema, but this felt like something she did on an afternoon instead of providing us with the intensity that she harbors. Then, to add more fuel to the fire, there was Richard Farnsworth. Again, he isn't a horrible actor, but it felt like Lynch picked him because he fit the role physically, but alas, couldn't master it mentally. Farnsworth seemed out in left field for a majority of his time on screen. I couldn't tell if he was trying to remember his lines or if he was truly in character. His eyes seemed watery for everything which brought too much emotion to those little scenes, and seemed to bring not enough by the dramatic ending. His entire speech about his time overseas at war was pathetic, while some will quote it as being his speech of a lifetime, I saw it as babble (and no, I am not that insensitive  I just felt it could have been handled by a stronger, more professional actor). The rest of the cast seemed equally as unimportant. I wanted Lynch to either go 100% for this film or none at all, but alas, it felt as if he just half-ed his way through this heap.Speaking of David Lynch, where did he go in this film? There were some scenes that I witnessed that screamed the director that I love, but then there were others that just felt like he took pointers from Ken Burns' "Looking at America" class. I hated the sweeping cornfields that seem to plague this film. Instead of keeping us by Alvin's side throughout his journey, Lynch gave us a repetitive view of farming and corn. There is nothing wrong with this technique when making the epic that one desperately needs to see once in a while, but when the same images were used over and over again, I nearly felt Lynch was humoring us with the dulls of Iowa instead of being the majestic all the critics raved about. I think he could have been stronger with his filler than what he was with this film. He needed something to couple with the authenticity of Alvin, but the stock-footage that he chose to show was definitely not the balance one could hope for. I also felt there was more to be discussed with the friends that he met along the way. Alvin was a walking storybook, filled with the way that he led his own life instead of listening to those around him and learning from their experiences as well. Lynch made Alvin very closed minded, which did not create a strong protagonist for the feature. Alvin was a strong character, but I needed more with this story. I wanted him to make choices, learn new things, and bring that to his brother's table when they eventually met. I felt cheated when this never occurred and felt as if Lynch was saying that this journey through Americana was that we could learn from Alvin, and not vice-versa.Overall, I wasn't stunned by this picture. I thought Lynch could have been stronger with his choice of direction and cast instead of what seemed like he just "played it safe". The overplayed stock footage of cornfields infuriated me due to the lack of time that we could have been spending with Alvin. Speaking of Alvin, why couldn't he have been a stronger, better-rounded character? I felt after watching this film that Lynch had duped me into believing that he wanted to paint a picture of America, but instead gave us nothing more than soft music, recycled images, and stock characters. The stories were interesting to listen to, but brought nothing fresh to the table. I must admit that the brotherly love moment brought a tear to my eye (since I have a brother as well), but why couldn't we focus on this further. Lynch made the riff between the two brothers seem like a toss in the pan, when it was the central focus of this film. The Straight Story could have been a strong tale bringing in a new image for Lynch, but instead it felt jagged and old. I could suggest one viewing for this film, any further, and you will see how dull those cornfields really claim to be! Grade: ** out of *****

reviews.review_title: Powerful and effective. It will hit a deep nerve
reviews.content: I am a huge fan of David Lynch. I am a fan of his surreal style, his 'moody' plot lines, his unexplainable mysteries. So being a fan of all that I knew I would see The Straight Story eventually (although it wasn't one of his that i was looking forward too much), but look at that. For all it's simplicity it is as powerful of a film that Lynch has ever done.I am so happy that Lynch is able to make a film like this. Before this, his most straight-forward film in terms of narrative was no doubt The Elephant Man. But even that film still has some really bleak and surreal imagery going on. Lynch has a really devoted fanbase, but I am sure many critics wouldn't have thought he would be able to direct a film like this. Lynch proves them wrong. He has a humanity and passion that runs throughout his films, and as much of a visceral and visual director that he is, he is also very much an actor's director. He has directed actors to incredible performances, like Watts in Mulholland Dr, Dern in Inland Empire, and Lee in Twin Peaks Fire Walk With Me. Richard Farnsworth is completely captivating in his portrayal of Alvin. He invokes such deep emotions and gives perhaps one of the most nuanced and subtle performances I have ever seen. This doesn't feel theatrical in one bit. For the film's emotional pull I always wonder how much a film can get away with before becoming corny and overly-sentimental, but to my surprise The Straight Story never crossed that path. It's because Lynch isn't trying to make us feel with editing tricks, loud sad music, or corny sentimental dialogue. It is all in his direction and in the actor's faces. The entire cast is pretty great. They all have limited screen time but they all hit a deep spot in me. This is an incredible film, as great as a film of this nature could be. Heck, I didn't even think I was going to love it, but I did. It is one of Lynch's best films and stands out in his filmography, making it all that more special.

A former Iowan, I loved how this simple story showed the home state that I love. Simple people, often elderly, with practicality over appearances; strong community bonds: the expansiveness of treeless vistas with oceans of stars and clouds and corn; deer: beer; Ragbrai; and the Catholic Church. The lead actor nailed every stubborn old Iowa man I ever knew. Classic.

Beware! The credits open with "Walt Disney Pictures present a David Lynch Film» and it's just surreal: having Lynch & Disney together for a movie, it's like having night and day at the same time.But those credits help setting the movie: forget Lynch's previous unintelligible works, filled with sex, violence, twisted dreams and fantasy. Here's you get a straight story, a biopic without any effects or make-up. Stripped of all his trademark, is a naked Lynch still among the best filmmakers ever? Yes, totally because if all the dark side of Lynch is purged, there is only left his bright side.With a story that seems impossible to direct (a road movie with a lawnmower), that break all Hollywood clichés (about old age, no violence, no guns, no sex...), Lynch delivers a naturalistic tale, a movie that is an hymn to the nature and the wisdom of old age. The lateFarnsworth has a face that says it all: Death is coming, it's time to confess the heart and to save the essential, the family. At 79 years old, he will have master his craft until the end and it's really a SHAME that the best actor award went to Spacey (being selfish and keeping the Oscar for himself, i wish he will have a shorter career than Farnsworth!). Hence, is-it a sign that he dies shortly after the ceremony? The other great loser of the movie is Badalamenti who scored his best soundtrack here: simple, moving, haunting. Just imagine the movie without his music and you'll tear its heart (for the fun, the best music ward went to the "Violon Rouge" by John Corigliano, great composer, 4 soundtracks in his career, none since the Oscar, ever heard about him?).Lynch was very sincere to shoot the movie in the actual locations because you really understand what happened to this old brother and you can seen the landscape changing along the road.In conclusion, if I have the same fun watching the speedy highway strips of "Lost Highway" as watching the slow national strips of "the straight story", then you can be sure that the director is indeed a master!

This is a lovely, lyrical story, exquisitely photographed, about the importance of human connections. The fact that it is a true story adds to the pleasure. The director is to be commended for his patient, careful pace, which matches the story so perfectly. Plan to see this one more than once!

This one is totally out of left field for director David Lynch of "Blue Velvet" fame. Nothing is weird this time, no midgets or strange dream sequences, just a straight forward story of a man who decides to ride a lawn tractor from Iowa to Wisconsin to visit his terminally ill brother.Richard Farnsworth is magnificent as the old man who has lost his drivers license due to poor eyesight. He rides his John Deere in what is one of the most interesting road movies I've ever seen. Sissy Spacek is the old man's daughter and Lynch just lets her act, and she is great, as always.The trip is heartwarming and a very different entry from David Lynch.

The Straight Story can really only be summed up in one word: simple. The title is all the movie is; it delivers what it promises. It is the story of Alvin Straight, a likeable old man who 'has seen just about all that life can offer', who has to travel on his lawnmower for six weeks to see his dying and estranged brother Lyle.Essentially it is just another example of the classic travel saga, an eventual throwback to such literary classics as Gulliver's Travels as it contains nothing more than a lot of long shots of seemingly endless country roads along with trials and tales that befall Straight and the people he meets along the way, including a very saccharine encounter with a pregnant teenager who has run away from home.The film-making itself is again simplistic; David Lynch has done some very good work with what is not at all a complex tale. A large number of long-held pauses between characters are beautifully timed as they inevitably mix to yet another long shot of a country road or a close-up of the tyres of the lawnmower as it continues to plow on across roads and boundaries. The repeated motif of the night stars is nicely used to illustrate the continual unity of people and family despite the distance, either physical, or emotional, between them.Finally, the lead performances are all excellent; Richard Farnsworth is perfectly cast as Straight and Sissy Spacek also does a fine job as his daughter Rose. However, some of the minor characters, particularly at the start, give somewhat one-dimensional performances that struggle to get the film moving; we really don't get a good insight into Straight's character until fifty miles into his journey, but from then on it's excellent acting all the way.Overall, the film is a warm, sentimental tale that provides uplifting drama and should bring a smile to all who watch it. 4 and a 1/2 stars out of 5.

reviews.review_title: Richard Farnsworth ends his distinguished career on an emotional but life affirming performance anchored by his captivating performance.
reviews.content: In the town of Laurens, Iowa, Alvin Straight (Richard Farnsworth) is a 73 year old man with failing eyesight and diminished mobility who lives with his mentally challenged daughter Rose (Sissy Spacek). When Alvin gets word his estranged brother Lyle (Harry Dean Stanton) has suffered a stroke 370 miles away in Mount Zion, Wisconsin, Alvin becomes determined to visit Lyle and make peace with his brother in the time both of them have left. As no buses go from Laurens to Mount Zion and Alvin has long since lost the ability to drive a car, Alvin modifies a riding mower and modifies a trailer to carry supplies and shelter as he travels the 370 miles to visit his ailing brother.The Straight Story is based on the true story of Alvin Straight a man who captured national attention due to his story about traveling 240 miles from Laurens, Iowa to Blue River, Wisconsin to visit his ailing brother using a riding mower. David Lynch's frequent collaborator Mary Sweeney learned of the story in a New York Times article in 1994 and had wanted to acquire the rights to produce a feature film, but the rights had already been secured by Ray Stark as a potential vehicle for Paul Newman (that was ultimately never made). Following Straight's death in 1996, the rights became available again with Sweeney acquiring them and co-writing the script with her childhood friend John Roach. David Lynch upon reading the finished draft loved it and set to direct the film with Lynch's first choice for Alvin Richard Farnsworth taking on the role despite hesitance as he was suffering from terminal cancer but took the role out of admiration for Straight. Filmed independently, the film had a successful debut at Cannes where it was acquired by Walt Disney Pictures. The movie was a massive critical hit with many lauding Lynch's divergence from his usual material and the performance of Richard Farnsworth was universally praised even earning Farnsworth a nomination at the Academy Awards for Best Actor (that unfortunately lost to Kevin Spacey's performance in American Beauty). The Straight Story is a strong character piece that is a challenging sit, but a rewarding one.At its core, The Straight Story is a meditation on what it means to grow older as we reflect upon our lives and the mistakes we made. Despite Alvin being presented with other opportunities to get to his ailing brother, Alvin remains steadfast in his commitment to make it to Mount Zion himself in what Alvin discusses as "swallowing his pride". Despite battling cancer at the time of production, Farnsworth gives us the same level of commitment and endearing eccentricity that earned him praise in The Grey Fox and as Matthew in the miniseries adaptation of Anne of Green Gables. There's a strong element of likability to Alvin Straight as a weathered salt of the Earth man whose pride has softened with age but remains steadfast in his principles. Spiritually speaking the movie has more in its DNA that links it to the works of Wim Winders than David Lynch as it's a road movie with very European sensibilities where the journey on the road is used for meditation on character and themes of regret and reconciliation. In between the lengthy sequences of Alvin traversing the beautifully shot landscapes of Iowa and Wisconsin there are breaks in the story where Alvin meets other characters along the way and shares his wisdoms while listening to their stories be they swapping World War II stories with fellow veterans or offering sympathetic ears to wayward travelers.Despite the themes of regret and reconciliation, the movie also features Lynch's trademarked off kilter sense of humor that only he can truly give us with memorable exchanges involving fraternal twin brother mechanics named The Olsen Twins, a woman who has a massive rant after being fed up with hitting one deer a week on her drive home from work, or Alvin's neighbor asking in a panic "What's the number for 9-1-1?" that adds so much needed levity to the proceedings to keep the tone from getting overwrought. The movie is very slow and deliberate with its storytelling as most of what we see is Alvin traveling via his mower but all this builds up to a deceptively simple ending that says a lot without saying much of anything at all and it's the kind of scene only two legendary actors, a legendary director, and solid effort from all three could give us to make a scene this quiet unleash a gusher of emotional catharsis.The Straight Story is one of the best films I've ever seen and Richard Farnsworth gave us a powerful and emotionally raw performance before his unfortunate death. Watching The Straight Story I was fascinated from the opening and fell in love with this story and its characters up until the quiet but very poignant end.

reviews.review_title: Like Raymond Chandler, the open road, old country music and John Cage: Uniquely American poetry
reviews.content: This is the kind of film where I don't wanna say too much...  Well, to quote the great American composer, artist and thinker John Cage, 'I am interested in forms that we can't discuss, but only experience.'  The Straight Story has to be experienced and then felt, then talked about.  One one level, it's about a man seeking a kind of spiritual and emotional redemption; to put things right.  Which oddly enough, is a main theme of Paris, Texas, which Harry Dean Stanton starred in.  Lynch surrounds Alvin Straight with lots of people going a lot faster than he is, while he himself prefers a slow and very deliberate pace.  It's a very potent message: slow down and see how much more you can see, experience and perceive.  A great change of pace for Lynch.  When it premiered at Cannes I'd heard that if you missed the credits, there's no way you'd be able to tell that Lynch directed the film. Not true.  The whole film is filled with great Lynchian moments and images. I knew I'd probably like The Straight Story, but halfway through I found myself deeply in love with the film's beautiful poetry.  Sissy Spacek and Richard Farnsworth both give remarkable and moving performances.  Farnsworth is the kind of great actor where he doesn't even need to speak because you only need to look at his face and you can read every thought.  Like I said above, uniquely American poetry of the best kind.

reviews.review_title: If this is old age, I don't want to go there
reviews.content: An old man, crippled and with bad sight, sensing that his life is winding down begins a journey to repair his fences with his brother. Along the way he re-lives a sad life and the many mistakes he made. The viewer is enticed to sympathize with the old geezer, but I couldn't generate much for the man. By his own admission both he and his brother drank and argued too much, and appeared to live the lives of bums. Good picture.

Alvin Straight (Richard Farnsworth) is an old man. He walks with two canes. He is nearly blind. He can't drive a car. His brother just had a stroke. He and his brother haven't talked for over 10 years. Alvin decides that he has to see his brother. So, Alvin sets off across Iowa headed to Wisconsin on a lawn mower. The movie is almost 2 hours of alternating boredom.  First we see shot after shot of Iowa cornfields being harvested and close-ups of asphalt whizzing by under the lawn mower. Interspersed, we are subjected to the homespun philosophy of this old man talking to people he meets along the way. Most of these discussions are melodramatic, trite, or disgusting. Melodramatic - Alvin discusses his W.W.II service with another man in a bar. Alvin believes he killed an American solider while serving as sniper in France.  He's never told anyone before!!! Trite - Alvin tells a group of young bike riders that the "worst part of being old is remembering what it's like to be young". Disgusting - Alvin tells a young pregnant runaway that she needs to go back to her family. Family is more important than the individual. Not only does this Kantian, proto-Nazi philosophy disgust me, Alvin had to use the old bundle of sticks analogy to illustrate it. Then there's the scene with the "woman driver" who can't make it to and from work without hitting a deer. (I guess that's funny, but woman driver jokes are hardly original.) The worst part of the movie is the acting of Sissy Spacek. She plays Alvin's mentally challenged daughter. She painfully draws out her stuttered lines. You think or hope that she'll choke on a word and no longer be in the movie. Not much to recommend.

The Straight Story is David Lynch's most heartfelt movie since "The Elephant Man."  For mainstream audiences, one might expect, it would also be their favorite.  Not so apparently; up here in the bay area the movie has all but disappeared.  What's the deal here?  Does nobody bother to see a G rated movie?  Doesn't ANYONE pay enough attention to quality in movies to know that Lynch is one of the country's best directors?  I wish this movie better luck in other countries, where maybe they take better notice of movie excellence and have the patience for a wonderful film like "the Straight Story."

reviews.review_title: "I know to separate the wheat from the chaff, and let the small stuff fall away."
reviews.content: Like a modern-day Homer work, a twilight American reflection and the most artistically honorable Disney film in decades, isn't merely about old Alvin Straight's journey through the drowsy hamlets and bucolic boroughs of the Midwest, but about the people he discover to notice and watch over him. You'd think it was a flight of the imagination, this Blanche DuBois pipe dream, if the movie weren't rooted in a reality, supposedly anyway. Straight is a 73-year-old man from in Laurens, Iowa, who finds out that his brother is failing and resolves to see him one last time. His sight is too poor for him to drive. He lives with his slow daughter Rose, who is hopeless at the wheel. Nor do they have a car. But they have a tractor, and the second Alvin's eyes happen upon it, he knows how he can drive the 300 miles to Mt. Zion, Wis. The first mower goes kaput, but he gets another one, a John Deere, hooks a small trailer to it, and intractably sets off.En route, we discover a lot about Alvin, including an anguished secret he has kept ever since the war. He's not an erudite guy, but when he talks, the words emerge like the bones of something very durable. The screenplay by John Roach and Mary Sweeney unearths rhapsodic balladry and profundity in the precise selection of the right everyday language. Richard Farnsworth says the lines with ideal tranquillity and sincerity. Since the film is directed by David Lynch, who deals in esoteric, terrifying films, we keep expecting the suspense to diffuse with what we feel will be obvious, for Alvin's journey to cross Frank Booth, Laura Palmer and Eraserhead's threshold. But even when he comes across a possible eccentric, like the hysterical woman whose car has killed over two dozen deer in one week on the same expanse of highway, she's not a sideshow act, and we identify with her. You can hit a good deal of deer on those country roads.Alvin's voyage to his brother is one into his past. He recalls when they were young and overflowing with awe. And his courtship and marriage. His Army service as a sniper. And about years squandered by drinking and spite. He has surfaced from the furnace of his failings as a better man, cleansed, down-to-earth, and people along the way seem to get that impression.In one town where Alvin happens after losing control of his mower, the John Deere guy he comes upon is Danny, who lets Alvin camp in his backyard. Alvin won't enter the house, for any reason. Danny's an uncommon guy, innately gentle and discreet. He personifies all of our own thoughts about this endearing old oddball. He tenderly makes suggestions, but Alvin is inflexible: "You're a kind man talking to a stubborn man." If Riordan, the deer lady, the two bickering twins on the way into town and a despondent young girl are the backdrop, so are the surroundings themselves. Cinematographer Freddie Francis understands how to stir up a countryside without making it too reassuring. There are pastures of swaying corn and grain here, rivers, woods and little bed barns, but the wind we hear sighing through the trees is a gloomy and lonesome noise, and we're reminded not of the landscape we drive past on road trips, but en route to a memorial service, or on autumn days when the roads are bare but the look of the sky and the smell of the air fill you with a meditative somberness. The faces in this film are among its riches. Farnsworth himself has a mug like an old crumpled wallet you just can't bring yourself to replace. It's been attached to you for too long.There's another old man who sits beside him on a barstool late in the movie, whose expression is like the onlooker to all time. And the actor who plays the bartender in that same late scene, the one who serves Alvin the Miller Lite, taps the perfect timbre: He knows how all good bartenders can appear like a chum bringing flowers to a deathbed. The film is such a rambling voyage that it's easy to forget Sissy Spacek's mesmeric performance as Rose, completely riveting in her behavior, mannerisms and utter altruism.The final shades are also spot on. Who will this fading brother be, and what will he say? Will the screenplay say too much or fumble for obligatory over-romanticizing? Not by any means. Simply because you have to see someone doesn't mean you have a lot to talk about. Regardless of how far you've come to see them. It's a gesture more powerful than any words.

I love this movie, even though it's not typical from David Lynch , save for some moments here and there (take the grocery scene with Alvin Straight's daughter and the clerk for an example), and even though perhaps I would never have watched it, had the director been someone else. Along with Lynch, composer Angelo Badalamenti also makes the transition to produce a film score that's rather unusual based on the career record. And it's not only the irregularity by way of which their - Lynch's and Badalamenti's - performances match. They both weave brilliance out of the most linear/straight simplicity.The film does sometimes go very directly for the tear-drop effect, but does so so openly as an old man finding unexpected audience, in you or any other stranger, would, in telling his story. You can't help but accept that as fair and be understanding to the whole venture. Richard Farnsworth shows us an especially likable character. He's witty, he does surprise you sometimes how much. At one point or another you'd think now he's surely in a dead end, but then he already seems to know the way on. No spoiler in telling you he uses a lawn mover to start with... A film full of respect after which you'll look at the star-filled sky and think, instead of the loneliness of standing on a planet speeding through empty space, making no sense, of how just a little care for each other can make this a great place.This film is essentially the opposite of 'Lost Highway'.

I can't believe that David Lynch who is the master of mysterious movies directed one of the most simple and best movies of 1999 .. and possibly his best right after his masterpiece "The Elephant Man".The plot is very simple yet is very interesting .. David Lynch gave Richard Farnsworth his opportunity to finish his career in movie business in one last "Straight" wonderful performance and possibly his best.Sissy Spacek gave an amazing performance playing "Rosie" .. a passionate woman who suffers from a few problems.This movie is simple, deep and meaningful at the same time .. it is slow paced but it works fine ..David Lynch should quit making mysterious movies .. he made enough of non-understandable movies .. we'll spend yeas trying to solve them if they are solvable .. he should direct deep-simple movies like "The Straight Story" & "The Elephant Man".One of the best road movies. One of the best movies in 1999.

Fifteen minutes into the movie and this is what your reaction is likely to be -- WOW !!! First the technicals : background score - superb, filming location - breathtaking, camera work - amazing, dialogs - something to remember, characters - straight out of haven ... i could go on and on. each aspect sufficient to ensure this movie in movies hall of fame.But let me talk about the heart. Did I say heart ? Yes sir, this movie has got a heart ! Sentimentality which is not mushy. Grandpa's lessons which you like to hear again and again. Families having so much warmth, you wish to be around with them always. Kindness which makes your heart swell. You are likely to sit in awe of this wonderful movie after it ends, not wanting to move. In a world of movies ridden with expletives you wouldn't believe a movie like this exists.Thank you David for bringing us back to haven !

This is the black sheep of David Lynch's filmography. Even Dune doesn't stick out as much as this because that still feels distinctly Lynchian in all of its deeply flawed glory. There's a single sequence that feels like the work of the man who made Eraserhead and Lost Highway, and it's integrated so well into the quiet tale of an old man on one final trip to visit his dying brother that it never sticks out. This feels like, to a certain degree, Lynch's The Age of Innocence, a movie that feels out of his wheelhouse but he demonstrates he can handle with extreme tact and skill. It might also be my favorite movie he's made.Based on the real story of Alvin Straight who drove more than two hundred miles from Iowa to Wisconsin to visit his estranged brother on a lawnmower the entire way, taking about six weeks to make the journey. Portrayed by Richard Farnsworth, Alvin is a well of experience and deep feeling, barely able to walk, blind enough to fail any driving test, and angry for ten years over an argument with his brother Lyle (the real brother's name was Henry) that he can't remember the specifics of. When he receives word that Lyle has suffered a stroke, Henry decides that the only thing he can do is go, and he has to go on his own. He hitches a trailer up to his old red lawnmower which breaks down a few miles out of town, and he's forced to buy a newer John Deere in order to make the trip.This is a road movie, and it's interesting how it's structured. The people he meets get progressively older as he goes. The first is a young girl running away from home because she's secretly pregnant. Using some homespun wisdom about family, he convinces her to go back home. He encounters a group of cyclists as they zoom past him on the road. Meeting up with them at their camp later, they cheer him for arriving and he tells them that worst part of growing old is remember being young. He witnesses a women driving alone who rams straight into a deer. She is beyond distraught because she runs into one a week, killing them all, and she loves deer.
