It's a true story showing that if you do want to achieve something you can. It shows the best of the pioneers in the rural sides of the US. Great movie. Especially if you do have a bro.

How could it be more straight than this? "The Straight Story" is a truly, amazingly beautiful work of art. It's so touching, sentimental, humble and so full of beauty that it really touches our hearts deep inside with this amazing portrait of the story.Richard Farnsworth performance is really meaningful and amazing. His eyes are so humble and true that you can read the whole man's story by them.And an amazing job by the genius mind of Lynch that this time he just rolled the cameras and simply told us a straight story.a must see!

Lovely piece of good cinema. This is one of those films that you see smiling and you do not know why. Well, one of the reasons could be that we are before one of the most surprising directors today, and he is able to film emotions.When you are watching the film you can feel what Mr. Straight was feeling when he took the decision to go to visit his brother with his "marvellous" John Deere. What changed in his mind?, what changed in YOUR mind when you watched this film?A beautiful fraternal love story.

I have always been a big fan of Mr. Lynch's films (although some more than others), and this film gives me a new and different reason to love him and his work.This film is quite different from the normal Lynch fare, but you can still feel the presence of the man in subtler ways than usual.Richard Farnsworth is as always wonderful and I desperately hope he gets some well deserved recognition for this work at the Oscars (not that it really means a lot but still...).  There isn't a bad moment in the whole film.  I can't say any more than that.

reviews.review_title: One of those films that manages to humble you
reviews.content: What a superb film. I watched this on my own as a random choice to fill a few hours of loneliness on a weekday night, and went to bed thinking a lot more about family and friends.This is one of those films you need to watch if you are having doubts about the human race, and I all know we do from time to time.

reviews.review_title: a simple heartwarming story. . . by David Lynch
reviews.content: Based on the true story of Alvin Straight, a 73-year old man who traveled six weeks on a lawnmower to visit his ailing brother.  A G-rated film by David Lynch, you say?  Indeed.  Lynch's style, including some long, disturbing shots, really amps up the tension in this film.  I kept expecting some ear-slicing psychopath to show up in a Cadillac, but it never happened. The film is more G-rated than "2001" is, but it ain't for the kiddies, either.This is a really fun and touching film.  After seeing it, I felt like going on a walk down a deserted highway myself, just taking in the world one step at a time.  Alvin meets an interesting assortment of characters along the way, some whom he helps and some who help him.  Sissy Spacek plays his mentally disabled adult daughter, the most Lynchian character in the movie.  And does a bang-up job, I might add.It's refreshing to watch a simple movie where you're rooting for the guy to get his lawnmower into that barn by the side of the road before the rain starts.  And lots of (to help you feel like you've been on a lawnmower for a few weeks) sweeping shots of beautiful farmland that make you want to move to Iowa and drive a tractor.  If it's in your neighborhood, definitely take an evening or afternoon and go see it.

Watch this movie for all it's worth...yet there is a magical moment of two WWII vets sitting in a bar drinking a beer that is the greatest moment of two men who never spoke of their experience as young soldiers for the first time. Like this movie, it feels documentary...but it is not! If you had a father or uncle of grand-father who fought in WWII and never spoke of his experience, get this movie just for this scene! It can bounce by, but it is powerful and done better than anything I have ever seen!

reviews.review_title: A hidden gem in the Lynchian catalogue.
reviews.content: "This trip is a hard swallow of my pride,"This is what I'd call a peaceful film. The Straight Story is an anomaly compared to the usual Lynchian type of writing, but it delivers a pure and authentic story with clear version of all the struggles and regrets of a simple elderly man at death's door. A story set throughout a journey, it examines the themes of aging, family, determination, reconciliation and most importantly forgiveness, Led by the amazing Richard Farnsworth's performance.I noticed that David Lynch couldn't help but put on some of his typical Lynchian characteristics (the snoballs woman and the deer lady).

On paper, this movie would sound incredibly boring.  The idea of a 75-year-old man traveling the country-side on a riding mower certainly doesn't have much appeal to it, but the real power behind the film is its charm and its intelligence.  Writers will not find a better study of what makes a movie work than "The Straight Story."The perfect example of this is a scene in which Alvin meets a runaway teenage girl.  She's pregnant and afraid of what her parents would do if they found out.  Alvin tells her a story about his own kids, long ago.  He had them each take a stick and break it, which they could easily do.  Then he had them bundle the sticks and try to break them.  "That bundle," he said, "is family."  So many other movies would feel compelled to continue and make sure we knew that an individual could be broken but together the members were stronger.  "The Straight Story" realizes that we're smart enough to understand this and simply leaves us to contemplate the thought and draw our own conclusions.Alvin's journey across Iowa is full of such refreshingly un-Hollywood character interactions.  Each interaction is full of warmth and humor, and Alvin is so cute riding his mower that we can't help but smile as he makes his way to Wisconsin to make peace with his brother, Lyle, who has suffered a stroke.  And the simplicity of the final scene emphasizes that the real story here is not the destination but the journey.  It's a journey in which Alvin shares his life with everyone he meets--to their benefit and ours. It's a slow, simple, relaxing ride meant to remind us of all that we've lost with the urbanization of America."The Straight Story" is the rare live-action "G"-rated movie that truly should not be missed.  Grade: A

reviews.review_title: Quite possibly the worst movie I've ever seen.
reviews.content: Alvin Straight lives with his "slow" daughter Rose. He is a stubborn man who when the doctor tells him that he needs to get hip surgery refuses on the basis that he simply doesn't feel like it. One day he gets a call telling him that his brother, Lyle, has had a stroke. Alvin decides he needs to visit his brother and make peace for the last 10 years (in which neither of them have spoken to each other), but since he can't see well enough have a driver's license, he decides to take his lawnmower on the 300+ mile trip, dispensing fortune cookie wisdom to anyone who he happens to come into contact with... and that's it. Yes, you read that right, "that's it". For two hours we watch a tired old man on a lawnmower.The entire movie is an exercise in blandness and mediocrity. Whether it's the one-note acting, the countless repeated shots of cornfields and the open road, or the repetitive score (which recycles the same two musical cues over and over again for the entire movie). The movie is so bland that when we finally have a tender moment in the bar between Alvin and a fellow WW2 veteran we, the audience, no longer care because we stopped caring about Alvin over an hour ago. Then when he finally gets to his brother, they say two lines to each other and it ends. That's it. We don't even find out exactly why they fought in the first place, other than a fleeting reference about saying nasty words to each other.Indeed we, the audience, find ourselves saying "that's it?" for the entirety of the movie. Early on in the movie, Alvin's mower breaks down so he gets a back ride into town, buys a new mower and starts all over again. That's it. There's a scene where Alvin stops to talk to some young bicyclists to tell them that he hates being old, and then the scene ends. That's it. There's a scene where a lady runs into a deer and goes off for minutes on end about how she hates continually driving into deer, and then she drives away. That's it. There is no conflict, there is no message. The only person who really learns anything is a runaway teenager who learns the importance of family, and she isn't even important to the narrative.It has always been a tradition for conventional movie goers to wonder how critics have come to love certain movies. This is no exception. This movie, however, makes one wonder how it even got past scripting, let alone garnering the praise of every respected critic out there. There is not a single good thing that can be said about this movie, other than perhaps it is one of the first real attempts to show that G rated movies don't only have to be for the kiddies (though this movie probably should have been rated PG for some mild language and alcohol use, but it's a minor quibble really), but that effort is not enough for me to even consider this piece of celluloid to be anywhere near watchable or recommendable. All I can say is thank heaven that I didn't have to pay to see it.one half star out of five *I'd give it zero out of five, but even I recognize that it takes a lot of effort to make even a bad movie so the half star is for the hard work that went into it. Aren't I generous?*

Not at all the kind of film one might expect from David Lynch, The Straight Story is a beautiful and moving film, full of warm and intimate performances. Each character we meet is unique and Richard Farnsworth's central performance is stunning.The visuals of the Midwest are captivating, really taking you on the journey with Alvin and it's capped perfectly by a tender and uplifting score.I'll admit that the first time I watched the film, I kept expecting the main character to find an ear by the side of the road or some other Lynchian weirdness, but what you actually get is a deeply moving thesis on ageing and the power of family. Easily Lynch's most accessible film but also one of his most intimate.

reviews.review_title: The problem of generation gap and more
reviews.content: The problem of generation gap is as old as the hills and has its impact almost in every family. It has been brought to existence by the rapid industrial and cultural changes in the world after WWII. Many scientists started researching this phenomenon, and many terms such as Baby Boomers, Generation X, and Millennials, describing people born in the years 1946-1964, 1965-1979, 1980-1995 respectively, appeared. Each and every generation shared its own values, goals, and ways of life, which produced the source of inability to understand each other across generations. Apart from the publications of many scientific papers touching upon generation gap and related to it the issue of aging, this phenomenon gave its theme also to many Hollywood productions. One of such productions is David Lynch's brilliant film The Straight Story. The Straight Story is based on true episode in the life of Alvin Straight, an elderly Iowa retiree who traveled three hundred miles on a lawn mower to reconcile with his brother, who had suffered a stroke. The film is filled with many small adventures and encounters that illustrate the issue of generation gap, as well as, the challenges and dilemmas of aging. Alvin's journey consists of series of encounters with a great variety of people that present different slices of those issues. He also manages to touch most of them with his wisdom, dignity and sense of determination in spite of his poor health. One of the persons he comes across is a runaway teenager. She stops at Alvin's fireplace, and he shares his supper with her. When she reveals the reasons of her escape, the old man's smart approach strikes the viewer. Instead of criticism, the runner away is told a story about a game that Alvin used to play with his children. In this game Alvin had given each of his children a stick and asked them to break it, which they easily did. However, when he asked them to join all sticks together and try it again, none of the children was able to complete this task. Then Alvin concluded to his children that those sticks are family. After the story they go sleep. In the morning Alvin realizes that the teenage left his camping and on the fireplace he notices a bunch of fastened sticks that viewers may interpret as the teenager coming back to her family. Throughout his journey we discover additional information about Alvin's life. Most of observations that we can draw from these facts concern aging. At one point, when he is invited by a group of cyclists to their camp, Alvin is asked a question: What is the worst thing about being old? Alvin replies that the worst thing about being old is remembering when you were young. When his lawn mower breaks in Clermont, Alvin befriends a local elder. They share tragic experience from WWII, and Alvin confesses that he accidentally killed the Polish scout who served in his military unit, and also how this event shaped his life. The viewer is presented with the character of Alvin's brother and their long lasting argument, which is the main reason for setting up his "pilgrimage" to his place in Mount Zion. He is determined to do it on his own terms, as it is the only way to obtain his peace of mind. Alvin is well aware that the time is passing and it might be the last chance to reconcile with his brother, Lyle. When after series of mishaps and adventures he eventually reaches his brother's house, the viewer is kept in suspension as Lyle does not reply simultaneously after his brother cry. Fortunately, after few seconds we can hear Lyle's voice, the two brothers reconcile, and we can finally feel relieved. Few films have examined the issues of aging and generation gap in such a simple, honest, but at the same time arresting way. The Straight Story moves slowly, which perfectly suits the theme of the movie. The cinematography, by Freddie Francis, is evocative, and features numerous shots of corn fields ready to be razed. Both story line and cinematography depict true images of the Autumn of a man's life. The images that will stay in the viewer's memory for a long, long time.

reviews.review_title: David Lynch meets A Trip to Bountiful
reviews.content:
There is no denying that The Straight Story is a film by David Lynch, even though it might seem far removed from anything Lynch would ever create. 
The Straight Story is about a 73 year old man facing the fact that he is not immortal and that death could very well be upon him.  As the story opens, he is found lying on his kitchen floor.  He has been there for hours because he had fallen and there was no one to help him up.  He visits his doctor who warns him that his unhealthy lifestyle has caught up with him and that if he doesn't shape up soon things are only going to get worse.  And then, the final blow, a message about his brother, who he hasn't spoken with for several years, comes in, telling him that the man had a stroke. 
Richard Farnsworth plays title character, Alvin Straight.  He creates a stir in the small town he lives in when he decides to go an visit his brother who lives almost 300 miles away.  With no bus access, and with Alvin unable to drive a car (poor eyesight) he hitches a trailer up to his lawn mower and begins a trek across two states.  Sissy Spacek plays his daughter Rose.  While she seems to be burdened with a mental handicap, she is his caretaker and knows him better than anyone.  Yet despite her feelings about his trip, she is not able to stop him.The Straight Story is filled with David Lynch's creativity as a director. As usual, Lynch captures the essence of small town living, highlighting the quirkiness of seemingly normal circumstances.The only Lynch trademark that is missing from this film (and I can't say that I necessarily missed it) was that element of danger he brings to his films.  Here is a story about a man meeting people as he travels the back roads of Iowa.   There is no violence and nothing to be afraid of. 
The Straight Story is very funny and at times had me laughing out loud.  But at the same time, there are several heart wrenching moments, as Alvin reveals some of the pain that he has experienced in his life.  Richard Farnsworth has been the second banana throughout his career.  His performance in this film had me wondering, "Where has this guy been all this time?"  Certainly Farnsworth is Oscar-bound with this role.Anyone going through a mid life crisis might find The Straight Story to be an interesting experience.  In one scene a cyclist asks Alvin "What is the worst thing about getting old?"  Alvin replies, "Remembering when you were young."

Simply put, The Straight Story is the most simple movie ever done by the director who makes the most complex movies I can think. So you were confused by Lost Highway or another Lynch movie. Well, The Straight Story is the opposite. You would really have to be a complete idiot to ask to the man sitting next to you "What happened right there, I don't get it". The story is simple: a man who sees his death coming decides that he wants to see his brother who just had a stroke. He hasn't seen him in ten years and has lost his driver's licence. He also wants to do this by himself, so he goes on the road with his lawnmower. This is when the movie turns into one of the most beautiful road movies ever. The beautiful photography and Richard Farnsworth's performance make this simple story a beautiful one, and the rest of the cast, mostly people he meets, are also great. My only problem with the acting might be Sissy Spacek, who overdoes it a bit in her role as Alvin's daughter but nothing really bad. It is simply that alongside Farnsworth's oscar-worthy performance, she doesn't stand a chance. The Straight Story is a movie you will either love or hate. I loved it but I can understand why some would hate it: the slow pace, the lack of action... But this movie is a beautiful reflection on growing old and a movie which touches the viewer deeply. You end up really caring about this old man's quest. Now, wether you love it or hate is up to you, but please, see it!90%

There's David Lynch and there's The Straight Story. It's truly a classic in American road trip movies but one that chugs along at 5mph. Not much to be said that hasn't been by someone else here but will say that it had a certain quiet charm. The doggedness of a war vet that endeavours to drive 300 miles to visit his dying brother, the corn fields is America and a rusty lawn mower. It's unreal how Alvin meets the best of America on the way, no serial killers, no drug pushers, just kindly folk going about their businesses. All in all a decent watch.

I was channel surfing on a lazy Sunday afternoon when I came across this movie. It was during the fire exercise and we see two couples who have set up as spectators to witness this sight and then we see an elderly man losing control of his tractor as he speeds helplessly down a hill. It was the look on his face that kept me from changing the channels and it was his humanity of this character that kept me mesmerized the rest of the time. Richard Farnsworth portrayal of Alvin Straight is one of the most honest performances I have seen in a long time. And true, the storyline itself does go at a very slow clip, but it is deliberate. I realized when he finally reaches his destination of why this was. It gives us a chance to experience first hand what a long journey it was for him, both physically and emotionally, and how long it can take to rectify things in our own lives. I am rarely so touched by performances and screenplays but this is a 'bible', if you will, to live by. Acts of kindness, forgiveness, humility and love propel this story to its touching and subdued climax.I intend to find a copy so I can watch it from the beginning and also to use it as a tool in my daily life to aspire to be a better human being to others and and most importantly to myself.Thank you to everyone involved in the making of this film and story.

When I went to go and see this film, I was wondering if Lynch would put in any of his trademarks 'weirdness' at the beginning or end of the film, like he did with 'The Elephant Man', and practically the whole of 'Eraserhead', and when I saw that he didn't, I knew that this was going to be quite a refreshing movie.I loved the bit where Lynch shows Rose looking out the window near the start at the ball rolling across on the road, with the child following shortly, then later on when we find out about her past experience with children we're given the shot of the ball rolling across again. Brilliant. I also liked the way Lynch didn't push it over the top with emotion at the end when Alvin finally got to see Lyle. He said he was going to see Lyle, and he did. No boo-hooing or 'I'm sorry, I'm sooo sorry!'.Farnsworth puts in a well suited performance as Alvin, pulling off the humour of the story with great style, as well as the more sincere parts of the film. I'm wondering why it was only on in just about one cinema in the whole of Northern Ireland. Great stuff.

* * * * * (5 out of 5)
The Straight Story
Directed by : David Lynch, 1999
`Tenderness can be just as abstract as insanity´ - David LynchThe Straight Story is a movie with such a rare form of momentum and style, a methodical lyricism, that it is not only the result of a somewhat directorial restraint (this is Lynch after all), but of true, unabashed artistry and inspiration.In perfect rhythm - chugging along - Lynch takes us to the beautiful golden farm country of America's heartland as in Laurens, Iowa.
We engage on a seductive journey (based on a true story), the journey of one Alvin Straight, an elderly man with bad hips but a positive approach to life, who decides to make ends meet with his brother. With whom he hasn't spoken to in years. The Straight Story touches and addresses human traits such as forgiveness, humility, success and love, without ever missing a beat. You are not laughing at the movie or because of a funny scene, but because you may have been there yourself. That kind of moviemaking is not a first at all, but seldomly is it this engaging, charming or rewarding. The movie rests nicely into its own, it glitters with a kind of self reliance and plausible charm, amidst the many organic characters and lush visuals. Richard Farnsworth as Alvin Straight is endlessly endearing, while Sissy Spacek is touchingly vulnerable as his daughter.The impeccable musical score - by famous Lynch collaborator Angelo Badalamenti - a tender mix of violin, guitar and simple orchestration - is also a peak performance. Not only does it play to the movie's strengths, but adds texture and depth when not enhancing or enriching already mesmerizing visuals. When viewing this movie and as the ending draws closer, you may find yourself wondering just how exactly Lynch will round it up. Don't. Neither unwillingly celebrational nor inappropriately dark, Lynch brilliantly goes full circle : the mother lode unfolds in a fashion that I doubt any one who would have deemed otherwise.A riveting journey; one of pure and vibrant human poetry. A classic in every sense of the word, The Straight Story is an absorbing and atmospheric masterpiece. A true heartwarmer.Note : kudos for going against hindering odds : based on a true story and also produced by Disney. Normally a dangerous cocktail. However, David Lynch and his superb cast pull it off : Alvin wins you over immediately and the Disney shadow? You never even think about that for a second.

Is the deposition of years not another mapping of life puzzles? 
From this point of view, the director David Lynch's deep understanding of the world is still the basis of the film.
Perhaps this straightforward fragmentation atmosphere is deliberate, but from a technical perspective, Lynch could make some details more elegant.
Of course, the overall expressiveness is still shocking enough, and when the actor reaches the level of Richard Farnsworth, the instinctive power in his body has transcended the performance itself.

reviews.review_title: I'm very thankful that I did'nt pass up this movie.
reviews.content: This movie was a nice warm delight to watch. I really enjoyed Richard Farnsworth's acting in this movie. I also enjoyed the people that he met on his journey to see his brother. I also enjoyed the cinematography of this movie. It was pleasant to watch the screen.I found the ending to be especially touching. I don't see to many movies where the audience stays seated to watch and listen to the music of the closing credits. This was one where they did.

reviews.review_title: One of the best of All time!!!
reviews.content: I saw American Beauty the other day and thought this was the best movie of the year. The performances of Spacey and Wesley were outstanding; perhaps Wesley like Carrey was robbed for not being norminated. Benning performance can either be seen as over-acting or someone who is trying to make a false face for herself and a makeshift image of success. Nevertheless, after seeing Richard Farnsworth performance in 'The Straight Story' I realised that Richard deserved the oscar if it was just a race between him, Spacey and Crowe. Whereas, Spacey relied upon good camera direction and words to convey emotions, Richard went a step better just by seeing his slow movement across the screen - he didn't even have to talk to convey ideas and emotions and when he did Richard as Alvin summed up World War Two far better than three hours of 'Saving Private Ryan' could ever do. For me this is the best movie I have seen since La Vita e Bella and that was over a year ago!!! This is one of the greatest movies of all time for the following reasons: 1) The acting by all the characters were outstanding, something you cannot claim for American Beauty. 2) The storyline was more thought-provoking as it's the type you will appreciate more when you are adult enough to understand. 3) There are moral lessons here that are far superior to American Beauty. What do you THINK!!!

This movie is simply one of the best movies ever.  The views are great, the humor is good and the acting is great.  This movie drives home the kinds of things in life that are most important but never gets preachy or sappy.  I think this is the first movie I have ever cried at.Another great thing about the movie is it is the first time I've seen Iowa in its true nature in a movie.  Being from north-central Iowa I could identify with the way the people were and every house and street looked familiar even though I have never been to most of the towns featured.
10/10

The most touching thing ever invented is old men with good hearts. This is a tribute to that man. I had a big grin on my face at the same time as I almost cried throughout the movie. One of the best movies ever. - 10/10

reviews.review_title: The pace of life that we think we want?
reviews.content: Certainly this is a slow paced movie.  We are so geared to lots of action that when we get into a movie that is less than hectic and where a scene doesn't change every few seconds we begin to think we should be bored.  A slow paced movie gives us a chance to reflect and to observe the surroundings, something we don't often give ourselves a chance to do in "real" life.  The Straight Story is indeed a chance to be involved with a variety of people and their impact on us and us on them.  Having said all of that I think the pace could have been faster than it was (I think of the pace of Patch Adams).  Still, glad I saw it.  I still think about it and the lessons I can learn from it.

reviews.review_title: A very enjoyable film with heart.
reviews.content: The Straight Story touched as no other film seen recently. Farnsworth's portrayal of the thoughtful and loving father, kind stranger on the road, and his stubborn streak all made me feel kinship with Alvin.Having traveled up to 400 miles on bike trips on highways and byways, I can vouch for the special flavor of the slow mode. The photography pleased me, especially when it lifted us up for the big picture of the beautiful countryside.

A moving, bittersweet film from David Lynch.  Richard Farnsworth and Sissy Spacek are terrific in this emotional comedy/drama that portrays the situation I believe everyone faces later in life:  How to deal with the past, recent and distant, and how to make amends.I can't say enough about Farnsworth in this role.  His facial expressions and tone convey almost as much as his words, and he nicely balances the comedic and dramatic aspects of the narrative, particularly when he embarks on his trip.  The scene where he has a beer with a new friend about his age is particularly moving, as the stories and memories they share have been in the news the past few years but never discussed in this fashion.Of note also are the scenes near the film's conclusion, when he visits with some very kind people while waiting for repairs.  Without going into detail, I found them to be an almost melancholy commentary on our society, as we realize that there aren't many neighborhoods or people who are like this anymore.  The film's final scene is very well done, as the veteran actors "show their stuff."All in, a memorable viewing experience that is recommended.  An "8."

reviews.review_title: G rating doesn't have to equal G-ross.
reviews.content: This film was a big achievement because it took weirdness, portrayed it as "normal", and managed to still get a G rating.. from DISNEY of all places. This is achieved by making the strangeness and unpredictability subtle enough that it could go unnoticed. I laughed hysterically during one scene - the main character, who has been travelling long distances on a lawnmower and generally acting weird throughout the film, is asked something along the lines of whether he was concerned travelling and potentially interacting with "crazy people". It was also very entertaining that few characters in the film remarked on his mode of transportation. The conclusion of this film was left open-ended, rather than tying up with a snap cheese conclusion... another aspect which is highly unusual for a Disney or G-rated film.

reviews.review_title: The Best Film of the Year
reviews.content: The Straight Story is so rich and thoughtful that it resonates for days afterward. It is so refreshing to see a movie that is character-driven. I have seen many comments which regard it as "slow-paced," but these must be folks who are accustomed to movies in which the action drives the characters. "Slow" is the last word I'd use to describe this film, which is so emotionally generous and exciting. Lynch blends in the vastness of midwestern American landscapes with the purity that they deserve. Richard Farnsworth speaks volumes with every wrinkle in his face, and emotions come across clearly with or without dialogue. His performance is one which breathed over me and reminded me how delicate and entrancing the art of acting can be. His every gesture and expression was a treasure to witness. The Academy should be fined for not rewarding him best actor this year...the same goes for the film.

There was an old TV show, Then Came Bronson, about a fellow who traveled around the country, dispensing wisdom and pithy commentary that helped folks straighten our their lives. The Straight Story definitely has some great moments, and some beautifully-filmed work (love that early camera sweep through Alvin's yard to his kitchen window) and the acting is generally very good. But most of the film is given over to Alvin's worldly wisdom, shared with a runaway girl, a couple of bickering brothers and a WWII veteran. "Corny" is the word that comes to mind (appropriately, given the landscape).Frankly, I was let down.

I require very little of the movies that I watch. But some movies just don't cut it. This proves that once again, David Lynch disappoints. Like any other David Lynch film, this movie is about as slow as they come. This does not necessarily bother me... I made it through a six hour "The Stand" (1994), and many other unnecessarily long films. But the problem with this movie is that it is laced with intermittent doses of bad acting, and a lacking story. Watching this film is like driving a tractor to the moon... forget state lines. A few beautiful and intellectual moments shine in this film. But if David Lynch thinks that he can cast just anyone because he plans to have them sit there and stare at the wall, he is dead wrong.

The Straight Story shares a lot with most other Lynch movies, in paying close attention to the weirdness one can find by looking closely at a small town. But while many of his other movies focused on menacing small town weirdness, this one looked at endearing eccentricity. In most hands, only the endearing qualities of the story would get attention, but Lynch sees the interesting oddness too.The movie is slow-moving, but not boring. The scenery would probably get pretty boring if you were driving past it, but the cinematography manages to find the beauty and interesting things along the way. But the real interest is the characters along the way -- the run-away girl, the twin mechanics, and the fellow veteran he trades war stories with.

On of the aspects of pin-pointing a good director is by being able to notice their atmosphere an technique. David Lynch has made past films which were deemed "dark", "noir" or "disturbing", but this film distinguishes his ability to direct, and his diversity as a director. He maintains his atmosphere with the long shots, drawn out with little, to no sound, then adding in a climax to a certain scene, yet still maintaining a certain level of tension and wonder. Dialogue was sparse, but important, there was nothing left in there which was not needed to further the story and the philosophy of the story. The beginnings of Lynch's films are always so powerful and apparent, which sparks an interest in what follows.  The noir-esque lighting was still apparent in such scenes as when Rose and Alvin were talking about the trip.  Not too many films use quite a sleek filming style, and this one ranks Lynch up with the finest (Kubrick).

If you liked Twin Peaks for the slow, beautiful, and above all, the intelligent way the story was told, you just have to see `The Straight Story'. You will love it! David Lynch has again showed that he is a brilliant director. This time he directed a true love story that you will remember for a long time.

reviews.review_title: The trailer was better than the film...
reviews.content: It is beyond me why this movie has been rated as of now (June 11, 2001) #100 of the 250 best movies of all time. When I saw the trailer for this movie, I thought to myself, "That looks like a great movie, I have to see it when it comes out." I never made it to the theater to see it, and boy am I glad that I didn't. When I got around to renting it, I watched this whole movie waiting for some to happen. Not once did anything inspirational or uplifting happen, let alone anything to help move the dragging storyline along. The musical score is just horrible. Well it's not bad at first, but that's all that you hear throughout the whole movie. Sissy Spacek did a horrible job with the speech impediment that her character had. Richard Farnsworth did a good job acting, but he didn't have much to work with. There isn't anyone else worth mentioning about acting, they were all very mediocre and amateur. I gave this movie a try, I really did, but it didn't live up to the hype. If you're still interested in seeing the movie, I suggest you watch the trailer, it shows all the best parts of the movie anyway. I give it a 1, yes a 1, out of 10.

Simple movie, featuring Richard Farnsworth in an amazing performance, as a old man who travels a long distance on a lawn-mower to get to his brother who had a stroke.  This true story applied to film- keeps a steady and head-strong beat.  It is enjoyable to watch and brilliantly done in a kind of stretched-out fashion. The characters met along the way, can easily be applied to real life.  People we meet each day, even if just for a second and never really knowing why, if we will see them again, or what we may have done for them with just a few simple words. This crystal-clear movie touches the heart and takes you to places rarely seen on film these days.

I'm not sure how well this movie would play on repeat viewings, but I've got a feeling it's best viewed by an audience caught off-guard, without any expectations as to subject matter or its director's prior excesses. THE STRAIGHT STORY is a slight one, its characters unassuming and its tone decidedly muted. If you can de-accelerate down to the film's slow tempo, you'll be rewarded with moments of quiet profundity. Though generally derided even by those who like the film, Farnsworth's scenes with the pregnant runaway are deeply touching: his analogy of a lone individual as a twig easily snapped, a family as a bundle of sticks tied tightly together and near-unbreakable, is a lovely moment that embodies the film's understated virtues. A beautiful Badalamenti score aids director Lynch immeasurably in achieving these grace notes, as does the sweeping imagery captured by cinematographer Francis. Farnsworth's face - a tintype of a vanished America - almost makes appraisals of his performance superfluous. While it's hard to say if THE STRAIGHT STORY would work the same magic on the second or third viewing, seeing it once in the properly attentive frame of mind should be enough to leave you with an indelible memory of it.

reviews.review_title: Easy Rider for the septegenarian set!
reviews.content: Loved the realistic pace and scenery of this film.  A nice depiction of the best parts of being old and the most frustrating parts of being around older loved ones.  Initially I feared it would turn toward the schmarmy but it never did and ended at the perfect point.  We didn't need a moment more or less.

reviews.review_title: Not typical David Lynch, but also stylish and enjoyable
reviews.content: It does not like a David Lynch film at all. All the quirk elements that hallmarked his film did not even make a transient appearance in this one. As its name indicates, the film tells a quite straightforward story. Mr. Straight, in his seventies, embarked on a journey with a vehicle adapted from his old lawn mower, only to satisfy his willing of meeting his brother recently hit by a stroke. The flick is slow-paced, and the combination of some mild community members and passers-by gave the old man what he needed to complete the journey. Frankly, it feels quite strange to see a heart-warming film that bears the name of David Lynch, but it is a good one of its genre.

The Straight Story is among the best movies I've ever seen...period. I never thought I would say this about a Lynch-directed film, but I say it without hesitation here. The acting is a bit stiff in the first few minutes, but once it gets settled in, I'm not sure I've seen finer performances. The film moves slowly, but deliberately, as Lynch demonstrates the power of silence. Angelo Badalamenti's score complements the film perfectly. The cinematography is unusual but is never distracting. The character development is outstanding, and the biggest surprise of all: the dialog is very strong and very intelligent. The emotional performances by the actors together with the very genuine dialog made the movie personal for me. Our kids even sat through its slow pace because the characters are so interesting. I just can't say enough positive things about this movie. If you want a good family film, this is it.

One of the few charismatic movies one can view.The will of avery old man to visit his brother living in Wisconsin and being ill due to a stroke.A man hoping to make a huge change in his life by attempting to travel on a tiny John Deere mowing tractor to make the route Iowa-Wisconsin:excellent field scenery of the States and adventurous scenes.The human touch looking for a new meaning in life even when very old in age.Relations are highly marked,characters are closely depicted and some scenes are approached very slowly to show an element of philosophical thought:amusing moments.Great movie!

reviews.review_title: One of the best climaxes ever shot
reviews.content: The Straight story is one of my favorite movies, even though it can be a weird movie for some. It surely takes few minutes before you get into the movie but the feel from the 1st scene is like there is some good quality stuff ahead. It is about an old man's journey and somewhat similar to 'Into the Wild' or 'Harry and Tonto' where you learn a lot from one man's experience with strangers, when he's on journey to a destination which he thinks is the ultimate destination. There are not many characters or dialogues in the movie but still is quite effective. The lawn mower idea makes it a unique movie at least for me. I wish the lead had won the Oscar because he pretty much single handedly carried this movie and does more than justice to the story and screenplay.

Lynch has created a wonderfully elegaic and lyrical world out of the cornfields of Iowa.  It is a part of America that is forgotten, struggling to keep its identity in a modern world, much like the main character. Certainly a welcome change from the blood and guts movies we're used to in the nineties.  This is good evidence that you don't necessarily need violence or sex in a movie to make it poignant.

Alvin Straight (Richard Farnsworth) lives in Lauren, IA, with one if his daughters, a Rosie () who'd lost the custody of 3 of her 4 sons, due to her mental illness. 73-year-old Alvin, with very difficulties in standing or walking, he receives news of a tricky stroke that attacked his brother, Lyle, who he hadn't spoke to in a decade, after a fight. Alvin didn't want to leave his brother in those terms, so he felt the need to meet him, the problem was he lived in Mount Zion, WI, and Alvin didn't have a driver license. So Alvin prepares his lawn-mower and starts his 390km trip in a 8km/h vehicle. He went anyway. The whole movie shows the many events that occurred in his long trip. Alvin Straight did in fact exist and also did this trip. Unfortunately died two years later and so did Richard Farnsworth. For them both I'll give a word of respect and applause. Alvin Straight, who's did we only understand from a 112 minute video but it's what it takes just to understand he had the most right notion of value. Richard Farnsworth, one of the late 20th century best actors whose roles shall not be forgotten. Although great deeds and great men provide great productions, the Straight Story is very simple but it doesn't lose any of its epic aspects. From this movie you will keep in mind his words. Deep, wise and meaningful. Obviously it ain't David Lynch's common job but it turns out quite an interesting movie. 8/10

reviews.review_title: a flawed labor of love; contains possible minor spoilers
reviews.content: `Disney Pictures is about to release a G-rated moralistic family picture by director David Lynch'.This press report caused an almost immediate hassle between the positive side of my personality and the side that likes to be referred to as `Realistic'. Since fortune favors the bold, Mr. Realistic took hold of the mike first and stated: `Think about it. 1990 was THE year for Mr. Lynch. The first season of the mini-series 'Twin Peaks' was popular to the extreme; his motion picture 'Wild at Heart' won the palm d'Or in cannes; his video for Chris Isaak's song 'Wicked Game' a chart topper; and calvin Klein got Lynch to make a series of commercials for his new Obsession perfume. Then came the clouds as the second season of Twin Peaks lost a lot of viewers, who simply had enough (a result of modern culture where we are like children, who stubbornly MUST eat a box of candy in one sitting and wonder afterwards they we got sick of it); the motion picture sequel Fire Walk With Me was booed at in Cannes and a world wide box office failure; his new TV-series On the Air and Hotel Room couldn't raise interest. After a silence of more than five years, Lynch returned to the silver screen with the motion picture Lost Highway. An intriguing film to be sure, but there were few positive reviews and a lot of people were disappointed. Mr. Realistic, whose speaking can always be somewhat exhausting and who often get caught in the moment, sighed and paused, thinking about how to put it. `In the beginning of 1999, Lynch tried it once more on the small screen with Mulholland Drive, but this time it didn't even get the chance to reach audiences as producing network ABC passed on the pilot. Lynch isn't a stupid man, so he starts thinking: 'It's been almost ten years since I had my last hits. The millenium is almost over and if I want to end it successfully, I've got to act fast.'  So, less than two years after his latest film, Lynch returns to the silver screen with a based-on-fact family picture about an old farmer road-tripping through the country. How can you possibly make an interesting picture with such a premise? This film's gonna be a sweet as sugar piece of corny and moralistic rubbish. Hence, positive reviews and oscar-nominations are almost secured. Hence, it becomes interesting (and save) again to invest in a guy like Lynch.'  At this point, Mr. Positive (who doesn't even want to be called `Mister') claimed the mike. `A director is more than the story he tells', he stated. `A director is the pace, the directing of the camera, the directing of the actors, the whole atmosphere. Besides, Lynch isn't a cold, emotionless creature. Blue velvet as well as Wild At Heart and Fire Walk With me contained dramatic, sensitive moments filled with love. Lynch isn't a David Cronenberg - He cares about his characters. And The Straight Story isn't Lynch's first 'normal' film, he gained interest with the acclaimed The Elephant Man.' Mr. Realistic, bold as ever, grabbed the mike for a moment and yelled; `Yeah, that other 'normal' film he made at a point in his career when he didn't have one.'.  Mr. Positive shook his head (because of both Mr. Realistic's bold character and what he said), but since he didn't have an other argument ready, he decided to end this first discussion by suggesting to take a look at the film first before judging it.The beginning of The Straight Story takes place in Lynch-county, alright. We hear the music of Angelo Badalamenti, rather peaceful this time around; we see quiet, dreamy images of a small town. These images remind us of Blue velvet, but, as the music already suggested, we stay on the surface this time. If there is vermin in the grass, Lynch isn't interested this time around. Mr. Positive scored (if you can regard a discussion as a competition, that is) leading with 1-0.  Indeed, the images (photographed by Freddie Francis) are obviously created by Lynch. The dreamy atmosphere, the slow pace and the humor are clearly his, too. And this film isn't all that peaceful, either. There are a lot of ominous shadows and the scene where Spacek watches out of the window one night and sees a young boy picking up a ball is scarier than those rope-jumping girls from Wes Craven's Nightmare on Elmstreet. But, after having played a poor first round, Mr. Realistic made a comeback. His opportunity knocked when the film ironically appeared to collapse when Alvin actually started his journey. `Well well well, Mr. Realistic cried out. `And For the first time since his first film Eraserhead, Lynch manages to keep the running time under the 120 minutes. How could that have happened?'Screenwriters John Roach and Mary Sweeney had to come up with stuff to 1. prevent the movie from becoming a one-man show. 2. Keep the story going. 3. keep balance to the story. To put it in another way: if nothing happens on the way, no film. Problem is that Roach and Sweeney didn't come up with enough anecdotes, resulting in a screenplay that shows the same ups and downs as the road Alvin is travelling down. Some of Alvin's happenings are strong and interesting (his story about W.O. II; the speeding down the hill; the small talk with the bartender), some comical (the encounter with the lady who accidentally keeps hitting deers with her car), some simple and serene (the passing bicycle-rally), others simple don't work, lead to nowhere, are corny or obvious (the scene on the camping ground; the talk with the girl who ran away from home). And every scene where really something happens is followed by long shots of the scenery and Farnsworth on his lawnmower, riding off to his next 'anecdote'. To summarize: there's a lack of evenness. Not only in pace and storytelling but also in quality. Fortunately, the last scene, in which Alvin reaches his brother Lyle, is not only the strongest one in the film but also one of the strongest in Lynch's whole oeuvre. There's barely any dialogue here, but Lynch proves once again that facial expressions and silence can say more than a thousand words ever could. So, Mr. Positive won after all, although it was a close call. As Marge Simpson once pointed out, bad winners exist, so Mr. Positive decided not to go on about the other winning expects of this film, like the brilliant acting by all concerned; the breathtaking cinematography by 80 year old Freddie Francis; and the courage of Lynch to, in this day and age, make a film about a elderly farmer on a 5 miles an hour vehicle (remember that wonderful emphasizing scene, messing with an audience's expectation, in which the camera follows the lawnmower, then tilts up to the sky to hold a few moments before tilting down again to show that the lawnmower has only progressed a couple of yards?). The Straight story is not a perfect film, but it IS wonderful and clearly a sincere piece of work, a labor of love.O yes, since fame favors the bold, Mr. Realistic was likely to have last word, anyway. Sneaking back to the mike for one last time, grinning sadistically, to point out a situation that has probably occurred a number of times. `Imagine, if you will, Pa and Ma Average, just having seen The Straight Story with cute little daughter Shirley and intending to see more films of 'that nice Mr. Lynch'. So, they go to the local Blockbuster and rent Blue Velvet. 'Gee, how come we never heard of this title before?'. Pa and Ma, settle down in front of the Zenith with their little daughter Shirley snug as a bug between them, hit the play button and are, once again, confronted with happy imagery of small town America. 'Look mommy', little Shirley chuckles, 'That fireman is waving at us.' Pa and Ma Average smile at each other. Ain't life the best? Then, the camera lingers into the grass and little Shirley's face becomes pale as a sheet. 'Don't you $@#&&* look at me!!'  Ha ha ha!'7.5 out of 10.

David Lynch is unquestionably one of the best/coolest film directors of our time. However IMHO 'The Straight Story' is maybe his best film. Richard Farnsworth is amazing in this film based on a real life story. Wonderful!

reviews.review_title: Harry Dean Stanton was a casting mistake
reviews.content: The other reviewers have said most of what I would say about this movie, though I must dispute the Hallmark comparison -- this is 1,000 times more genuine than anything Hallmark ever did.What hasn't been mentioned is this movie's biggest flaw IMHO, the casting of Harry Dean Stanton as Alvin Straight's brother. The entire film has been journeying towards the meeting with Lyle Straight, so it really takes you aback when the person to shamble out of the shack is not "Lyle Straight", but actor Harry Dean Stanton. Stanton looks NOTHING like Richard Farnsworth -- he's dark and swarthy to Farnsworth's ruddy and snow-haired. Lyle also doesn't look anywhere near Alvin's age (though surprisingly Stanton was born only 6 years after Farnsworth, in 1926).Lynch loves to re-use a stable of actors, and since no other major roles in this film utilize his favorite actors, perhaps he felt he needed to make up for it by casting Stanton. I think it was a major mistake, however, since it wrenches the viewer out of the world of the movie at the worst time. Just a theory, but I bet if Jack Nance (may he rest in peace) had still been alive, Lynch would have cast him as Lyle Straight. Nance appeared in all of Lynch's films until his death, and would have been able to pull off the role even better than Stanton, and had the advantage of looking MUCH more like Farnsworth. It's truly a shame he wasn't given that opportunity.

Despite being a full grown man and devoted David Lynch hater, I ventured into the cinema to see this film. And boy was I surprised! It made my eyes well up more than any film I can remember, and that's hard to do. Richards Farnsworth's performance as the old geezer Alvin Straight is nothing short of Oscar-worthy. So nice to see that someone in this world still dares to tell a story where cheap dramatic thrills are not present. Any other scriptwriter or director would have thrown in the robbing of Alvin, or how young would have trashes his trailer or beat him up to create "drama, conflict" (like they learned in filmschool). None of that here, and I'm so happy that was the case. Truly a straight story. Alvin encounters friendly people, just like in reality. It also reminded me about my trips to America: this film truly shows the greatness of America and its people, not everyone is a gun carrying NRA maniac. And the slow pacing is also completely deliberate and justified in this film, since Alvin is an old man and life to him move at a slower pace. His 7 week lawnmover ride to see his ailing brother, is just not only a trip on a machine out of nescessity, the time it takes is also a wayfor Alvin to "swallow his pride" as he says, to be able to make peace with his brother before he dies. Great, great stuff. Without a shadow of a doubt, the best film of '99.

When I see David Lynch and an 8.0 rating, I will of course see the movie.
But, but but: what is going on in this movie? Nearly nothing. An old stubborn man wants to repair a broken relationship with his brother. Stubborn means he will not use any of the facilities of the 20th century: neither bus, nor train, nor car, nor anything else than his mower and trailer. That's about it. The end? He meets his brother living in a shack and their eyes say it all.
Cinematography? Nothing out of this world: large fields with large agricultural machines.
Still defending an 8.0??

Brothers, rather than Leonard, that is.Lynch here ditches the surrealism of Twin Peaks and Blue Velvet for the beauty and melancholic Americana of, well, Fargo.  And it works a beauty.This is one of the slowest movies you are ever likely to see.  Not a lot happens.  Guy has stroke.  Brother gets on lawn mower.  Sad music plays. Nice sunsets.  Duo meet. The end.And therein lies the beauty of The Straight Story.  It is a movie of reflection and tenderness (tenderness being a recurring feature in Twin Peaks oddly enough), rather than fear or evil or suspence and questioning. Just as Fargo - to my mind the brothers Cohen greatest work - hides and merges beauty with horror, hilarity with melancholia, so does David Lynch in this utterly gorgeous study of lost American relations.I really love The Straight Story, it has happy bits and it has sad bits and the music is great.  That'll do for me.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as some people says, not as good as other says
reviews.content: SPOILERS ALL OVER IT.The title says it. This odd David Lynch movie (in fact, a very conventional movie for Lynch standards, and a very odd one precisely in account of that) follows the adventures of Alvin Straight, a 73-years-old man who decides to go see his brother Lyle, who he hasn't spoken to in years, in a rather unusual way.The movie has a beautiful photography and some great shots of the American roads, but that's not enough. Although it has its absolutely great moments, it lacks of easy sentimentalism in some parts. The good and the bad, then.The good. The acting: Richard Fansworth and Sissy Spacek are great. The opening thirty minutes are priceless and one of the most enjoyable ones I've seen recently, with a very subtle humor and genuine moving scenes. And the brilliant scene with the deers.The bad. Some of the conversations are too "cry, goddamn it, cry" specially the ones with the pregnant girl and the WWII vet. And when the old man rejects a lift because he wants to travel by himself, it just doesn't seem too believable with the character.A good movie anyway. I wouldn't have put it into the first 250, that's it. But the fact is, "Shawshwank redemption" and "Lord of the Rings" rank in the first 10 places, and they are crap. This one is pure gold in comparison.SAY NO MORE.

reviews.review_title: SPECTACLE from a Mystery director David LYNCH
reviews.content: I was simply amazed and astounded watching this beautiful movie, my respects are on high roll for lynch. I couldn't stop myself writing a review , it'll be my second.The life which is bitter-sweet around the candy rolled, is spontaneously captured in this phenomenal smart and simple true story. The love between the family, real harshness of synthetic agony and prosthetic proud, and how it will roll you down to the bases. An inspirational pro-founding for the young.For most of the people out there it's not a movie about some dramatic romance, or a family conflict, It's something that is very rare to find in this cinema, It's about the graces, serenity of being in living, the life which is usually, not pour very much influence upon us to give a little importance to it.May I must say this movie ought to capture more audience, but it seems these days it's all hell loose, who cares.. damn.

reviews.review_title: End Of A Long Road for Alvin Straight
reviews.content: David Lynch's (1999) film of John Roach / Mary Sweeney's story is set in Iowa and Wisconsin some time well before the film's eventual release.We come into the life of Alvin Straight (Richard Farnsworth) late on in life. His medical condition is poor, his life is mostly behind him and he knows it.This makes what he decides to do, even more remarkable and endearing. He decides (and at every point in the film his own name reverberates through his actions) to put a few things straight.Alvin is, by this time in his life, a man of great experience but modest means. His daughter Rose (Sissy Spacek) struggles with a speech impediment that makes communication a great effort on the audience's behalf. But it's worth it, because Rose's story cannot help but come out as the film progresses.This film is the story of a journey. But like all journeys it is a journey in the geographical sense and in the human sense. Early on in the film, we begin to understand that this is an ambitious journey, which no elderly gentleman of Alvin's age should reasonably undertake.But along the way, we slowly learn how Alvin has so many qualifications which equip him to achieve his unlikely objective. His objective is very simple and straightforward. His brother is ill and likely to die and he wants to visit him. He has had a falling out with him many years ago and they have not spoken in a very long time.Along the way, Alvin meets many people. The way he behaves towards them and the benefit they get from having known him is the essence of this film. We come to know who Alvin Straight is, from what Alvin Straight does. And at the end of the film, we know who we are .. better.

reviews.review_title: One of my all-time Favourite Movies.
reviews.content: The best thing I can say about this film is its very close to my heart. The first time I saw it, it left such a profound impact on me that I can never forget. The film is based on the true story of Alvin Straight's 1994 journey across Iowa and Wisconsin on a lawnmower. The character of Alvin Straight is portrayed realistically by late actor Richard Farnsworth. Sissy Spacek plays the role of his daughter, a kind woman with an intellectual disability. It is a road trip movie, plainly speaking. During the journey, he meets various people and shares his experiences and moments from his life with them. All the characters in the movie are surprisingly kind which is rare to see in movies today. Under the surface, it is about growing old, family bond, loss, suffering, mistakes, promises, and human kindness. The ending is just perfect and gives the required closure to the story.The story was brought to life by a master and my favorite filmmaker, David Lynch. No one could have done it better than him. The cinematography is beautiful and captures the beauty and simplicity of the American countryside which we rarely see in American films. The screenplay was written by John Roach and Mary Sweeney, which is the strength of the film and contains realistic dialogues. The highlight of this movie is the score composed by Angelo Badalamenti. The music is sublime and transports you to the countryside.The movie gives the message of showing kindness to strangers and caring for your family. The plot might sound too heavy and emotional, but trust me it's not. The movie is not overly sentimental and truer in showcasing real people and emotions, however, it will make you teary-eyed. I have seen the movie multiple times, alone and with my family. It is a family movie but can also be appreciated by the youth.

reviews.review_title: A beautiful, economical and hearfelt movie
reviews.content: One of the great keys to telling a great story on film lies in not what is said and done, but often what isn't. The Straight Story is exactly that: a story about sticking to the essentials of story telling and leaving out anything extra.  It is so promising that this film was made even at all. All too often, Film makers treat their audiences like idiots and feel that every motivation, thought and reaction must be dictated through rapid editing, snappy one-liners, super stunts and CGI effects all set to a blaring soundtrack. The Straight Story is a movie about quiet truths and requires the audience to fill in the blanks.  Fine case in point: in the film, Alvin Straight (Richard Farnsworth) listens to a woman vent about running over deer. As she screeches off in her compact car, Alvin simply stares down at the deer. Usually, the filmmaker will insist upon some quick quip that comments on the action and the character, but not here. We simply move on to see Straight cooking a piece of venison over a campfire while being stared at by deer molded lawn sculpture. There are many other sequences just like that in this rich film.  Sissy Spacek, Richard Farnsworth and the rest of the cast give fully fleshed out and three dimensional characters. The film is quietly moving without the slightest hint of sentimental seasoning. Thank you David Lynch for creating a genuine work of American Film Art.  A 10 out of 10.

The straight story was a really touching film, its music was great and really sentimental. I was expecting something weird from David lynch. but found the film a really nice enlightening piece of work. A fantastic performance from Richard Farnsworth- cruelly ignored for an Oscar or some type of achievement award. R.I.P.

I'm writing review about a film that I haven't watched for about a year. However before that it had been 4 or 5 times I had that pleasure and it's just now when I decided to comment. The straight story is the tale about the journey to the beginning. Well , they say that childhood comes two times in life. Once in the first years of life and another at the end of the life, off course if you're lucky enough to reach old age. But that's not the childhood i want to talk about, but the thing around the childhood, cause that's the time when you're i guess "Truest" of all. And you are also part of family, part of what gave you a birth and what in fact you are. And all the family members are part of you. But then comes the time when you go away, you become a little bit stranger. However when you become old you want to rejoin your roots. And that's what Straight Story's magic is. Alvin Straight is making journey through the beautiful landscapes of America but also he's making journey to the past , and that past is future, and both of them are the combining parts of that "Truest". And what Alvin does on the road is just to share everything he learned during his life with people who still have time to go that road. Straight story has the most natural philosophy of all. Here are neither suffered Bergmanic faces talking about the deep spiritual emptiness, nor the half smiling Godaric faces talking about the meaning of life in metro. Here everything is clear, everything comes to the surface and that's what makes the movie a masterpiece. Lynchs dynamic a little bit bleak directing, Badalamenti's masterful score and photographer's outstanding work off course are also in business. I do really think that it's the greatest Lynch film ever. And probably the best picture of all 90's.

People my age are not supposed to enjoy films like this. When they were designing this movie, it's doubtful that they had college-aged people in mind. After members of my family had rented it, I had planned on catching the first 20 minutes of the movie to kill a little time and then watching the rest "later". (Later almost never comes) However, after watching the first 10 minutes of the movie, I was hooked.Definitely not a typical David Lynch film, here he shows that he can pull off a touching, sweet, G-rated film. This is a great character-driven story with all around good acting . The people are real and three-dimensional, and while the plot may seem simplistic, it genuinely works. This is one of the best family related films to come out in years.

reviews.review_title: I love action/adventure/fantasy movies...& this one?
reviews.content: I hate soppy dramas, I hate the whole emotional touchy feely genre (every copy of Love Story should be incinerated) so was this this movie a surprise. It swung in at me out of left field with a vengeance, I tried every trick to get out of going to see this with my wife but she saw all the excuses coming and I found myself trouping into the cinema like a condemned man. But, what a evocative, gentle and humourous treat I found, superb cinematography and score set the scenes and the performances suited the understated mood of this movie. Excellent. (But I still think every copy of Love Story should be burnt!)

reviews.review_title: I seem to be in a minority .....
reviews.content: Well, its lonely here in criticising the "Straight to sleep story". One huge dollop of double sized sentimental americana goo. "Straight to afternoon cable TV story" is a better title. Definately for over 50 year old yankees. Lynch sells out to HBO??? What really annoys me is how easy it seems to be to get an average film into the top 100 by making it so inoffensive and actionless ...and actually plotless..the premise is so week that we never find out really why he stopped talking to his estranged brother ..all down to drink apparently, which the main character (who's name escapes me due to film induced narcolepsy) has given up of course. A disney film I note, so good wholesome on track messages. ARGGGGGH! Bring back the Love Bug!! And if I wanted pictures of endless cornfields I would have got a FREE travel brochure..not that there is anything remotely romantic about driving in the mid-west in the burning hot sun.

reviews.review_title: 10 for the first 20 minutes, 7 for the rest
reviews.content: The first twenty minutes of this film are of the best I have ever seen. Especially the air pictures of the Mid-Western landscape and the landscapes in the faces of the elderly in Laurens.Unfortunately Lynch does not succeed to continue the atmosphere of the beginning through the whole film. And thus it is not an absolute masterpiece, but nevertheless highly recommendable.The music deserves an extra applause.

reviews.review_title: THIS was directed by David Lynch?!
reviews.content: "The Straight Story" is a truly beautiful movie about an elderly man named Alvin Straight, who rides his lawnmower across the country to visit his estranged, dying brother. But that's just the basic synapsis...this movie is about so much more than that. This was Richard's Farnworth's last role before he died, and it's definitely one that he will be remembered for. He's a stubborn old man, not unlike a lot of the old men that you and I probably know. "The Straight Story" is a movie that everyone should watch at least once in their lives. It will reach down and touch some part of you, at least if you have a heart, it will.

reviews.review_title: Brokaw's greatest generation, with real regrets
reviews.content: I join with the viewers who highly praise this film.  This is very much a David Lynch film and a myth making performance by Richard Farnsworth.  The movie gains in mythic size each time I re-see it. *****Spoilers**** Let's consider a couple things touched on in other comments.  This is a simple story but not a straight story.  Alvin's story is one of a guilt ridden murderer, mean drunk, absent father, maybe even negligent caretaker of his own grandchildren. Not one comment says anything about recognizing older people in Alvin. His character is so vivid I can smell him. Believe me when I tell you the essence of Alvin's existence is spread throughout an entire generation of men leaving this mortal coil at this time. I put this film in the company of Lonesome Dove, Ikiru, McCabe & Mrs Miller, and  The Unforgiven.

reviews.review_title: A compelling drama that has 'David Lynch' written in unusually shiny letters.
reviews.content: This was not expected from David Lynch. A rather straight, uneventful movie with no hallucinations (Twin Peaks), character-juggling (Mullholland Drive) or anything like that. The surprise in this movie is that it ties you right into the wonderful character of Alvin Straight and the people around him. Although perhaps an un-Lynchian movie, the themes and symbolism are definitely David Lynch. Those who are familiar with his work will enjoy digging up all the double and hidden meanings while people new to Lynch have a very good introduction to his way of thinking and directing. People are afraid that they may be bored to death when they read the plot. It is indeed not a movie for fans of action or even conventional drama. But anyone willing to see more behind The Straight Story will have a wonderful trip. This movie goes deep. Way deep.

reviews.review_title: Lynch's best work to date, a beautiful picture of humanity
reviews.content: David Lynch is full of surprises. The Straight Story is a film you definitely wouldn't expect from him: it's true, straight and sentimental, but not too sugary at any point.The movie looks and sounds wonderful. Freddie Francis makes probably the greatest long shots of his career, and Angelo Badalamenti's music is. Sissy Spacek and Richard Farnsworth reach performances beyond compare. Harry Dean Stanton has only one line, but it's possibly the most touching as well. But still the best part is the film's script; it's just incomprehensibly good. There isn't much dialogue, but every conversation is filled with little big words of wisdom. "The worst thing of being old is remembering what it was being young." All these little things form a genuinely touching portrait of a man's life.I definitely think The Straight Story would've earned more awards the year it came out. It's good to see that more and more people are slowly starting to find it, and now it's getting the respect very well deserved.My score: 5/5

First of all, you have to sit back and ponder the possibilities for a film directed by David Lynch that is a Rated G Disney Production.Okay?Now, take those thoughts and boil out the negative ones. Because this film is great. It is intense and beautiful. I do recommend this to take children to, but make sure you give them a good dose of sugar for the first half hour (because it's slow). But it picks up the pace and ends up being a charming, philosophical look at life.This is based on a true story about an old man who, upon hearing that his brother had a stroke, decides to drive a lawnmower 300 miles to patch up some bad blood because, basically, blood is thicker than water.

The acting in this film is really outstanding. The main character is so much like my father, a humble and wise World War Two survivor. The greatest generation approaching the end of their lives with dignity is superbly depicted. It is understated and allows the viewer to be drawn into the experience of the main character.
Richard Farnsworth was wonderful in this, as usual. So heart-warming and just a feel-good movie.

The beautiful, aesthetic piece of work by veteran director David Lynch. Starring the brilliant Richard Farnsworth as Alvin Straight, giving us the most touching performance since MIDNIGHT EXPRESS.  Alvin is travelling through small towns, and David Lynch shows us the simpleness of such towns. David Lynch making this film is breaking out of shock and showing us what a worthwhile director he is.  *****

reviews.review_title: This is what life is all about.
reviews.content: Far from the "Matrix" and the "Mummy," on the other side of the world from a Jackie Chan kick fight, and worlds away from "Star Wars," there lives a world of just 'regular' folks. And as they get older, their lives take turns that make them reassess where they have been and what they have said. Who they may have hurt along the way.Alvin Straight, (Richard Farnsworth) can't get a driver's license because of medical problems, won't get surgery for heart problems, and won't get a walker just because his hips are giving out. But he can still do one thing. He can get on his old, rusty lawn mower and head out to visit his estranged brother, Lyle (Harry Dean Stanton), even though that is over 300 hilly miles away.If you find yourself choking back tears as this poignant journey progresses at 5 mph, through bad weather, odd lost people on the side of the road, and warm and wonderful people who help Alvin make this one last trip of his life, you won't be alone. And even with all that, you will be happy for Alvin. And wish you had come to know him better...maybe even be his next-door neighbor, or buy him a beer--chat a while to know a real person with malice toward none. Don't miss this one, even though the DVD had no extras whatsoever. Did Farnsworth get the "Oscar" for this? If not, he was robbed. (DVD movie reviewed here.) 10/10 stars :-)

reviews.review_title: gear down and enjoy this warm film
reviews.content: David Lynch tells this story plain and simple .. and slowly. For typical moviegoers, this gem of a movie could seem unbearably ploddy; but its great beauty and depth are revealed through its pacing, when one is able to breathe with it and let reflection and thoughtfulness rule rather than the need to be entertained. The first scene sets up what will be the flow and tempo of the rest of the film. Silently and without music, the camera seems to move at super slow-motion as it zooms in on Rose's house and yard, then her neighbor as she settles into her lounge chair to sun herself. No added drama or orchestral flourishes, just real life. That's how the movie unfolds to its end. It is acted superbly and with great humanity by Richard Farnsworth (who died just a year later) as Alvin Straight and also by Sissy Spacek as his slightly retarded daughter Rose. It's a compelling and true story of a 73 year old man who drove over 300 miles from Iowa to Wisconsin on a John Deere lawn mower hitched to a trailer in order to try to reconcile with his estranged brother, who had suffered a stroke. Along the way, he meets a number of people, some of whom aid him in the long trek as his tractor breaks down, and others with whom he shares the wisdom of 73 years of living, and his own mistakes and failures. Especially moving is his conversation with another World War II veteran as they remember their harrowing experiences and the heartbreaking loss of their comrades. Throughout the entire movie, Lynch retains his focus and ability to keep things simple and unaffected. Some of the scenes are set up so naturally and organically, one feels as if they've stumbled onto the real event or conversation as it was taking place. This is my favorite kind of movie-making, because it allows the viewers to come their own conclusions and experience their own emotions without ever telling them how they should feel. I've seen the film twice and it has made me cry both times, both for its truthfulness and resolve, and for Farnsworth's incredible portrayal. He was 80 years old at the time and had already been diagnosed with cancer during the filming.

THE STRAIGHT STORY makes the best of everything that is at hand.  Best of the story, the scenery, the actors, the music and the directing.  This is a study in nonverbal cueing. And the nonverbals speak volumes.  David Lynch has crafted a minor masterpiece with this film and Richard Farnsworth as Alvin Straight is remarkable.

I find it hard to think of anything negative to say about this movie, but I also can't quite share the enthusiasm of the other commentators. The music was really beautiful, I must admit to that. And the scene where Alvin meets the lady that keeps on hitting deer is hilarious, but I don't know, to me this is "just" an every day story. Maybe this was also David Lynch's plan, and if true, he succeeded very well. But if you go to the countryside you meet people like Alvin everywhere, they might not use a lawn-mower, but they are not that much different. And it might be a more interesting idea to go and have a chat with them instead of watching this movie, unless you live in a city of course;)

I rented the DVD based on the comments and votes of the other IMDB members. While not always an accurate yardstick, more so on small films than big studio stuff. This film had all the qualities I love in movies: great writing, great casting and some breakout performances. Spacek was phenomenal. Although her character was not central to the story, she was so on character I had trouble believing this is same person that was the "Coal Miner's Daughter". The movie had just enough fantasy value (never got pulled over by the Highway Patrol??, never ran out of gas??, never got run over??) to keep it from being a docudrama and yet a story not so far from probable to make it real.I gave it 9 of 10 and a hearty recommendation to all.

I have always been fascinated by David Lynch and his intriguing work in movies. He is way different from others but this movie is a real gem. The main character Alvin assures us that we can overcome our mistakes and take the correct decision. Another good thing about this movie is the nice way in which he is able to meet and get along with strangers. This may be considered a taboo but this is a nice way to meet new people and appreciate them. The performance of other characters is also nice and the way this movie has been shot is really captivating. It is a fact that even an unusual story in the hands of a capable Director can bring joy to anyone. It is an appropriate movie to catch on a weekend and feel great about life and its gifts.
