One of the most poignant is his conversation with a fellow old timer about their deeds during the War. Another favourite scene is when he's talking to a runaway about the strength to be found in family. Visually, I have always liked David Lynch's work and the Straight Story, despite being a massive departure from his usual surrealist approach is trademark Lynch. The cinematography is simply stunning. The wide camera angles and slow movement conveys and enhances the American midwest and seems to compliment  somehow the peaceful yet dilligent frame of mind of the central character. Richard Farnsworth is brilliant as Alvin Straight. Deep rheumy eyes and a heavily wrinkled face show a man who has lived and yet burdened with with his own regrets. The supporting characters that Alvin meets along the way are good and honest people. Such a nice change from all the badness in the world. And his final meeting with Lyle, his brother, is pure magic. Hats off to Harry Dean Stanton who, when he asks Alvin if he drove all the way on a lawnmower just to see him and Alvin says yes, the look in his eyes he gives back closes the film beautifully. Put simply, The Straight Story is an honest and gentle tale of human goodness and only those without a soul could find this film less than enjoyable. Definitely one for the DVD collection and a movie that deserves to become a classic. Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: As Forest Gump said, "stupid is as stupid does."
reviews.content: When Alvin spends $350 for a John Deer lawn mower to transport himself 265 miles to see his sick and estranged brother, I was wondering why he just didn't buy a bus ticket. Since this is a true story, I'm still wondering. At some point, Alvin does mumble something about not liking buses but it didn't sound very convincing. Hey, he looked pretty darn happy when he hitches a ride on a bus full of old ladies. So, here's a man that leaves his somewhat retarded daughter to wonder where he is for about a month, he uses corn fields for a bathroom and I'm supposed to get all teary eyed watching him ride a lawn mower down a state highway. There's a scene in a bar when Alvin exchanges war stories with another old guy and I was expecting him to reveal some battlefield trauma he'd received that would explain his bazaar lawn mower trip. Wonder how he got home.

For me this was pure torture to sit through this movie that was getting such rave reviews and being proclaimed as such great art. It was slow with meaningful filming such as a ball rolling by slowly in one scene. From the dialog, to filming, to the story line it was just not well written or filmed in my opinion. As many rave reviews as it got I assumed it would be an enjoyable experience but what I got instead was me wishing I had picked any movie other than this one. If you like watching a tractor and farmland for many scenes and such art as a ball rolling slowly by then you will love this movie. If the repetitiveness of the same looking scenes over and over gets tiresome and slow story line and dialog then think twice as there are few movies I ever get up and walk out of and this was one I wanted to leave but didn't.

Merciless portrayal, yet full of sympathy. Never seen so much suspense in a movie so devoid of "action". THE TRUTH as seen by a sensitive eye. "He was a little fellow." (2x) I am going to watch those much publicized but underestimated early David Lynch movies again with new fresh eyes.

The Straight Story marks a very important landmark in David Lynch's film career, a very welcome changing point, in my opinion. Lynch has finally broken free from his post - modern shell in which he has been locked up and what we get is an explosion of humanity, in story and (for the first time) in visuals. The Straight story is a  love declaration between Lynch and America. There are no negative characters, from the priest to the redneck, they all get a fair, compassionate, treatment. There's no trace of cynicism in the somewhat off beat characters (no cynicism? in the 90's? can that be?). Its nice to see that on the dawn of the new millennium there are still some frank, feeling people in the movie industry. It has been a long time since I've seen the audience stand up in the theater and applaud.

This was my favorite movie of 1999. Richard Farnsworth was aptly described in one review I read as "pitch perfect." The soundtrack is amazing, and the film has a slow, gentle pace that could have been boring but is truly lovely.

I'm not in the habit of commenting on movies I've seen, but people, go see this movie. I'm not a fan of road movies, but what David Lynch accomplishes in this movie, is not just great, it's brilliant.Alvin Straight's an elderly guy that hears he's in bad health. When his brother is reported to have a stroke, he's determined to go visit him - driving throughout an entire state on a lawn-mower.Those are the facts. It doesn't prepare you for the sheer emotion of the film, the way the random encounters and conversations grasp your attention and, at least in my case, brought tears to my eyes on more than one occasion.And finally: Richard, wherever you are now, thanks man!

although it did not make me cry, it definitely touched edge of my heart and trembled my soul. it is sometime hard to believe the presence of those kind of remarkable people around. but they are for sure all we need to do is look.the story was great and the subjects of uprightness, self-sacrifice, love, courage and respect wouldn't be embroidered better and the social matter eg. willingness of running away from home or the truth that makes us ourselves,corruption of neighbor relations,(even though it is opposite in the movie one can understand what i mean if compares)so the first thing i did after watching it was ringing my mum, dad and brother rather than crying.it is really a piece of good work.

reviews.review_title: It's hard to believe this was made by the same guy who brought us Blue Velvet and Mullholland Drive
reviews.content: If i can be honest, this is only the first David Lynch film i've seen in my life. But i still know all his other films, though, and i can clearly say this doesn't look at all like a Lynch movie. I mean, when we think about David Lynch, we think about bizarre imagery, shocking violence and hard-to-watch scenes. But this one has no violence, no profanity, is G-rated, and it's even made by Disney.Premiering in 1999, The Straight Story tells us the real story of WW2 veteran Alvin Straight, played by Richard Farnsworth in his final film role, who lives in Iowa with his daughter Rose, a woman with an intellectual disability played by Oscar-winner Sissy Spacek. Alvin has difficulties to walk and he spends most of his time on a lawnmower. When he discovers that his brother Lyle, whom he hasn't speak with for many years, suffered a stroke, he decides to travel from Iowa to Wisconsin to see him again and make amends with him. And since he's too old to drive a car, how does he travel there? With his lawnmower. I know it sounds crazy, but it's true. The journey is long and kinda boring. But at the end, he reaches his destiny and gets to rejoin his brother.Fun facts: 1- This movie was shot in chronological order. 2- Richard Farnsworth was terminally ill with bone cancer (so much that he committed suicide the next year), making him hard for him to stand up. 3- Farnsworth only accepted the role out of respect for Alvin Straight (by the way, both of them were born in the year 1920) and also when Lynch assured him there was no profanity in the film.What can i say about the movie? It's based on a real story and it's pretty realistic. It's dialogue has been compared to the works of Ernest Hemingway. It's acting is pretty good. Richard Farnsworth was magnificient as Alvin Straight. In fact, he should've won the Oscar that year (i'm not saying Kevin Spacey wasn't good in American Beauty). The soundtrack by Angelo Badalamenti is pretty moving. While i do consider that it was a bit exaggerated to nominate it to the Palme D'or, it was still a very good movie.Despite that, the movie still has some flaws. For instance, Rose's way of speaking was a bit annoying. I know she has an intellectual disability, but it's still annoying. Another thing is that the film is a bit boring. And the ending scene is a bit too rushed, since Alvin and Lyle barely exchange any dialogue. But i still understand that, just like Doug Walker (a.k.a. Nostalgia Critic) said, it showed us all the difficulties Alvin had to go through to finally join his brother.Honestly, is a pretty good movie. Is amazingly acted, pretty realistic, and it's contrast with the other Lynch films is pretty amazing. I'd wish Disney could still make live action movies as good as this one. And i consider that Farnsworth was a pretty underrated actor. I truly recommend The Straight Story.

reviews.review_title: A masterpiece from David Lynch, again.
reviews.content: If David Lynch were to turn into a small island just off the coast of Cannes and do the can-can to the strains of "I've got a lovely bunch of coconuts" it would fail to surprise me. Two things did surprise me about this film. The first was the "Walt Disney presents" in the opening credits. I would never have thought that Disney and Lynch... Lynch and Disney... but there you have it. The second surprise was in the ending credits when it became apparent that this was a film based on a true story.In many respects this film is like The Elephant Man in that it tugs on the heart-strings in a restrained way. The Straight Story had me weeping at one or two points, and chuckling in others. The slow pace, masterful use of silence, and the cinematography and soundscape all added up to an unassuming and beautiful masterpiece.Having spent so much time in the small-town America of Illinois I was immediately at home with the scenery and the pragmatic characters depicted in the movie. The film has a lot to say about being old and having regrets, but delivers a positive message to us all.All in all, David Lynch, who is one of my favorite directors, has created another movie that will take pride of place in my movie collection.

Incredible how boring a movie can be.The friend who selected this movie a year ago is still regretting it, we have not allowed him to pick a movie again... when he selects a movie, any other in the group will say "remember 'The straight Story'?" and he will humbly shut up.1 out of 1, today I was in good mood. And the landscapes were actually beautiful, that is true.

Only watched this film recently in 2018, I don't know why I have a huge obsession with this film and still do to this day, it's such a simple and poignant story. About an older man, visiting his brother who he heard got a stroke, and wanting to see him one last time. He travels 300 miles by a lawnmower of all things. the film doesn't convey a lot about the main protagonist Alvin, every now and then he slips out little things revealing more about his character. The whole time you just wanna hear more about what Alvin's got to say, giving life advice, his up bringing, his ideals, living in the middle of rural America in Iowa, his interest, his hobbies, how he didn't want to get the bus to Wisconsin to visit his brother, or ask a family friend, or anyone he met on the way, he was so adamant about doing this on his own and it makes you wonder why the whole time.(Spoiler ahead)
He does it! meets his brother played by Harry Dean Stanton only for a short scene, they hardly say anything, nothing profound, and the film ends with Alvin looking up at the sky, and the sky turning into the night sky the same way the film starts, I wished there was more words that were exchanged between the 2, before hand they didn't speak for over 10 years over an petty drunk argument, wished they dove into that a bit more, about their past relationship, I don't know... The film's great! non of my friends won't like it, but it's an interesting watch.I love how this is a true story, that took place in the 90's, the film was set in the 90's (obviously), and was MADE in the 90's (1999) I love films that are set and made in the time period it's set a made in, like in 'The Basketball Diaries' (1995) Although the story took place in the 70's, the director wanted the movie to be set in the 90's.The Japanese poster for the film is one of my all time favourites as well as it's aesthetics used, in the poster is Alvin driving the lawnmower at day time, but the sky is black. I hardly see any other medium of art depicting this, not even Photoshop of a beach in the middle of the day with a black starry night sky instead of a bright blue sky, wish there was more art like this, and also love to know who designed the Japanese B5 Chirashi Flyer poster!One of David Lynch's least likely films he's made, produced by Walt Disney Pictures, I'm not sure why he wanted to make the film initially, but I'm glad he did, I'm also glad Richard Farnsworth got the nomination for Lead Actor for this film. Apparently Richard was in a lot of pain due to his cancer during the shooting of this film, which I'm fascinated with and at the same time saddened, it's interesting how something like that could bring a lot more depth to the character, seems a bit method which I'm guessing wasn't Richard's intention (maybe for David's but who can really say for sure, I doubt it was), Richard was of similar age to Alvin, David even once said in an interview that Richard was born the play him which I love.After watching this film it's made me want to watch more Richard Farnsworth films, buy a really good CRT TV, and watch old westerns or films in similar vein to this one, kind of like shows that Quentin was in to that are depicted in 'Once Upon a time in Hollywood' with Leo's character.
And even go to rural America and learn more about the culture of the Midwest, why small towns exist, how they come to be and where are they now, and all of that.
I love to know any other films or shows similar to The Straight Story, the only other film I can think of is Nebraska (2013) Which coincidentally I'm also obsessed with.

reviews.review_title: Lynch plays it straight, with remarkable result
reviews.content: I find The Straight Story to be, contrary to what many have said, a very Lynchian film. But I haven't been witness to a more melancholic Lynch since The Elephant Man. One central thread in Straight Story is, just like in the black-and-white Anthony Hopkins drama, repressed emotions and people who are misunderstood because of their appearance or behavior. It seems Lynch has picked up the thread from then, and placed it within the context of the mythological rural American framework he has spent the last ten years developing. Considering his devotion to strong visual ingredients, at first it would seem inappropriate for Disney to put its hallmark on the result, but it's not. For the most part, Lynch plays it cool; only a few times giving in to the temptation to develop the bizarre aspect of the situation ("the owls are not what they seem").The main character, Alvin Straight (Richard Farnsworth), bears a striking resemblance to those furrowed old men often turning up in the work of Donald Duck cartoonist Carl Barks. The film starts off with Straight receiving word from his brother, who lives a few states further east. Having had no contact the last then years, the two have resorted to denial of each other's existence. Straight is haunted by thoughts about the past and an unfinished feud with his brother, and decides to drive and visit him. Neither in possession of a driver's license nor a car, he chooses his only means of transport: A lawn mower.Multiple technical problems break up the journey, which for us results in a lot of beautiful scenes from rural America each time Alvin stops to receive help from friendly locals (unlikely, at times). Judging only by the landscape scenes the film is quickly placed within the road movie genre, but taking into account the story, it lacks the eruptive quality of most such films, in stead harboring a concentrated quiet, like in Paris, Texas. Straight's trip echoes his past, which was spent partly traveling around.Richard Farnsworth is charmingly clumsy in his portrayal of Straight. Coming across as a self-consciously old man with all the right answers that indicates that he has surrendered to the inevitable biological decay. Essential enough, though, Farnsworth reveals a youthful aspect in some of his expressions that clearly marks him off from the other elderly people he meets. It is as if Lynch wants to tell us that Straight is not fixed, has not surrendered, but is still in motion with an intention to continue shaping his life. That way it feels like a double warning to "seize the day": Both in Straight's personal mission, and in the contrast to the other elderly, who shake their heads in disbelief over the weird ideas from a person they regard as "nuts". Farnsworth grins and chews with wandering, intense eyes, working his way through elaborate reflections over life in general, sitting around countless camp fires and at bars and other situations that simply invite to getting philosophical. Lynch is remarkably economical with the moral statements such situations easily could be fitted with, making Farnsworth's part in it subtle, and the metaphors about family and aging seem like slips of the tongue.Recommended (7/10).

In any respect. The major drawback is that the main character is a bit too idealized. Still, the acting, direction, cinematography and soundtrack -- a triumph. Funny, too. Except to people in Braunschweig.

reviews.review_title: A beautiful, gentle film that, nevertheless, is indelibly a David Lynch movie.
reviews.content: Richard Farnsworth, in an outstanding performance, plays Alvin Straight who is so determined to patch things up with his estranged brother (Harry Dean Stanton) he leaves his Iowa home and travels to Wisconsin on a riding lawn mower.  This absurd situation must have appealed to Lynch's penchant for the bizarre, but Lynch plays it, well, straight.  Basically a picaresque tale of Alvin's journey and the people he meets along the way and how he affects their lives.  Most moving is a late night campfire chat with a pregnant runaway, a harrowing exchange of WWII horror stories, and the brief but poignant brotherly reunion.  Lynch manages to make the material his own: odd industrial-noise sounds appear, twin brothers feud and even Everett McGill makes an appearance.  Really a lovely film

This story spoke to me in many ways.  The determination of one man to accomplish something his way, and giving to others along his journey. There were many memorable scenes, some laughs and some tears, but definitely worth the effort to see.  I felt moved by several scenes:  the young woman hitch hiker was terrific and the scene in the bar with another older man recalling their WW II experiences.This is a film that I will remember for a long time.  It spoke to me about family and its importance.

reviews.review_title: Essential Viewing for Young and Old
reviews.content: This film is in my list of top ten greatest movies. It's clear from reading the other comments that no matter where in the world you happen to live or language you speak, this film has had a deep emotional impact on almost everyone who has viewed it, myself included. Very few films have had this kind of effect on me. Over the past few years I have become increasingly exasperated at the quality of films been produced by the Hollywood studios. Once in a blue moon a gem appears from nowhere to put these studios to shame. Straight Story is beyond criticism, end of story. 10/10

What a gentle, heartwarming story. I was pleased to find that David Lynch can actually direct a nice, quiet movie. Wonderful cinematography and score, by Angelo Badalamenti. I've always liked Richard Farnsworth and was pleased to see he could still evoke such emotion. Sissy Spacek also did an excellent job playing his daughter, and all the secondary characters were equally well-cast. Just a nice, leisurely story.

reviews.review_title: A linear Lynch and a little great Character
reviews.content: I've seen much movies "on the road", but this is the most dramatic and the most simple, too. It represents something of extraordinary for the spectators (and I talk for audience and moviegoers), but even for the genial Lynch, the director of this movie, who doesn't usually make linear movies: he prefers to play with flashbacks and anticipations, and his filmography is an imposing demonstration of it. I think about Twin Peaks and my brain explodes if I remember the mental confusion which it has provoked in me XD. But this movie is different. Firstly, it's a true story. Alvin Straight, the protagonist whose surname becomes a brilliant pun with the plot so linear, had really traveled in 1994 for 240 miles on a 1966 John Deere Iawn mover like the movie told us. In fact, "The Straight Story" is dedicated to his memory, because he's died in 1996. After this, we have an excellent protagonist: Richard Farnsworth, in his last interpretation. He makes life to a Character whit the "big C", because he can show us all the longing which an old man who does a similar trip certainly had. Alvin Straight becomes in my opinion an American Dersu Uzala, or a Don Chisciotte who manifests us how nothing is impossible, and we can defeat our own windmill or slope (physical and moral). Any other character in this movie is treated with the greatest care for detail which only Lynch can use for them. In brief, a great movie whit great characters (in particular Farnsworth-Straight), a great director and a great, linear story, for think and for remember our own past (or future: it depends on age! ^^) and for put all old grudges against everybody aside. SEE HIM!

reviews.review_title: All I can say is 'Its beautiful'!
reviews.content: The Straight Story is a beautiful film. Shot in the North-eastern part of the United States, it never missed any flavors available. I just didn't want the movie to be over. And beyond the beauty of the movie, the real beauty lies in the characters. It seems there are only good people in this world. Right from the loving father and daughter, the doctor, Alvin's friends and neighbors,the lawn mover seller, the bus driver, the women on the bus, the woman who hit the deer, the cycle riders, the family who recovers his lawn mover, the old man who buys him the beer, the mechanic brothers, the padre...everyone of them. I just wish if the world was like that.I'd like to mention a few incidents too. Alvin's friends though they ask him not to go never laughs at him when he returns with the broke carriage. They rather express their empathy. The woman hitting the deer gives the impression that she is upset for her car or time but it ain't. She says she loves deer. The family who receive Alvin want to drive him to his brother's and the scene where the husband tries to convince his wife about this is exceptional. Even that run away girl proved to be loving. And of course the great message that war is not fought between countries, not even between soldiers but between innocent men who just want to earn for their lively hood.And of course the cinematography was excellent and the scoring was sublime. Altogether a must watch especially if you don't get disheartened by the slow pace.
One brother takes a trip on his lawn mower to mend his relationship with his brother! Great movie!

IMHO Too much cliché ! This movie could be stopped after 20 min (just after the deer scene). The photography is basic. The characters are propotypics and the dialogs look like a sermon. Why the heck did Lynch showed us the exactly the same sunset 4 times ? In other hand, the actors are really good but it's not enough to save this movie.

I watched it once 20 years ago or so, and then it didn't leave much of an impression on me. Maybe because I expected something different from Lynch, or maybe because in order to appreciate this film, one simply needs to grow up.I rewatched it recently, and now I apparently have grown up enough to appreciate this movie. First of all, now I saw that the movie is actually very Lynchian in spirit, in atmosphere, in cinematography, in sound design. It has all the typical Lynchian cinematography techniques in almost every frame.Basically, it's a road movie, but a very unusual road movie. But it is also a philosophical tale, full of symbolism, and it is this aspect that I was able to perceive only now.What struck me the most is probably the fact that this story is based on real events that actually happened to a man named Alvin Straight who, in 1994, actually undertook such a journey. The movie was filmed in the exact town the man lived in, with the help of local organizations and residents, and the film crew undertook the same trip in order to shoot the movie (Lynch talks about it in one of his interviews).I once heard Lynch saying that he attributes special importance to a story. A story told at the right time can change a person's life. And this movie is to a great degree about that. Each of the characters the protagonist meets on his way hears only one of his stories, but the viewer hears all the stories and sees how they change these characters; and at the same time the protagonist has his own story, unifying all the stories into one. So the entire film is a meta-story told by Lynch to the viewer. I found this moment just brilliant.The name of the movie is thus both a pun and as play of meanings: the straight story turns out to be not as straight as it might seem.

Richard Farnsworth and Sissy Spacek are incredible in this movie. The cinematography and sound are also fantastic. This movie will move you to tears (Or at least really close to it) no fewer than 5 or 6 times. Do not get me wrong, this is no sappy tear jerker. No one ever cries on screen. The emotion hits the audience without overt emotionalism on the part of the actors. If this movie had been promoted like The Sixth Sense, or even American Beauty, it would have been a shoo-in for a best picture Oscar.

reviews.review_title: Best performance by an inanimate object
reviews.content: Bundles of sticks have had a good year in film. They made their debut as a scary harbinger of doom-to-come in the highly over-rated low-budget hit of all time, "The Blair Witch Project" earlier this summer.They play a just-as-ominous but much more subtle role in "The Straight Story," David Lynch's wonderful G- rated film based on a true-life story of 73 year old Alvin Straight who drove his riding mower across two states to visit his ailing brother.The Bundle of Sticks revives its role from the over-hyped "Blair Witch Project" in much the same way it appeared in that film, showing up one morning outside the protagonists' tent. Here though it is a symbol of strength and one that returns a wayward girl to her family instead of taking her further away."The Straight Story" is just that - quite the departure from the American master of the surreal.Shot with all the care and attention to detail we expect from Lynch, it is not without his trademark quirks. One sequence involving Alvin buying supplies for his journey features a Lynch favorite - the un-scripted buzzing fly that wanders into shot. Lynch - unlike most directors - instead of cutting the shot - leaves the fly in and even generously amps up the buzz just cause he can.But while his quirkiness defines his other films the "Straight Story" needs none of that heavy handedness. With the help of a few odd ball characters - watch for the double-pricing Olsen twins and the method acting of the Bundle of Sticks - Lynch has created a film that deserves at least four Oscar nominations come February. (Unless of course they develop a new category for Best Performance by an Inanimate Object which The Bundle would easily snap up.)As Alvin, played authentically by stuntman-turned-actor Richard Farnsworth, sets out on his near 6-week journey his story and the story of those he encounters unfolds with all the ease and pace of a road movie slowed to 5 miles per hour. The "bread basket of America" lends itself easily to picturesque setting suns, old timers milling about and combine harvesters gathering grain to create our daily bread.Lynch utilizes this natural canvas to moving effect. Alvin has his story to tell and Lynch tells it not in a spoonfed expositional way, but through little parables he delivers to those he encounters along his journey up and down the hills of Iowa. In a credit to Lynch and his team of editors and writers not one word is misplaced, not one sequence too long. (Lynch and John Roach get the writing credits.)There are moments of pure Lynch scattered throughout this heart-string-tugger that wouldn't be out of place in other Lynch visions; The long open highway and its screen dividing yellow line ("Lost Highway"). The sprinkler system that can't get itself to shoot higher than 6 inches while in the background a child chases his ball (the "Twin Peaks" TV series). And the plucky score by Angelo Badelamenti (everything good Lynch has ever directed.)But the "Straight Story" does something that all the other "men at a crossroads" films of late eschew; men can change - even old men - not by virtue of violence but by going against everyone's advice and simply taking that inertia and making a move. Even if it is at 5 miles per hour.

reviews.review_title: Incredible characterization, little dialogue but what there is is wonderful. Brilliant.
reviews.content: Richard Farnsworth was brilliant in this beautiful film that was rightfully slow. It is hard to imagine David Lynch making a "G"rated film, but his unique hand is evident (twins again!)A film of great character, beautiful scenery, and words valuable in their sparseness. I loved it!

reviews.review_title: David Lynch directs a small gem of a movie.
reviews.content: A unique story, quirky characters, fine acting, isn't this what moviemaking is all about?  Toss in a few vintage David Lynch moments and you have a surprisingly moving and effective film about one man's enDeereing journey to make peace with his ailing, elderly brother.  Richard Farnsworth's face conveys more emotion in any one scene than most actors can generate in a whole movie.  And Lynch does an excellent job of reflecting life and American values in the "great in-between."  This is an understated small gem of a movie.

In an age of ever larger explosions, gaudy but unconvincing CGI, and endless 'wire-fu', it is a pleasure beyond words to find a film that foregoes these things and concentrates on a story that is nothing but human. Alvin Straight (Richard Farnsworth), a 70-yr-old farmer with a speech impaired daughter (Sissy Spacek), has a stroke, and this reminder of his mortality spurs him to find and make peace with his estranged brother. The problem is that to do this, he must travel 320 miles across America. Without a driver's licence. Ever resourceful, Alvin mounts his lawnmower and begins his quest. And that, really, is all you need to know. The beauty of this film lies in the majestically serene view that director David Lynch takes of Middle America; the picturesque vistas without echo the innate human goodness within. The elderly Alvin Straight, wonderfully underplayed by Farnsworth, is impossible not to like, and on his journey we learn, via his episodic meetings with assorted strangers (who never remain strangers for long), more about him and the reasons behind his voyage. If you're after sound and fury, forget it. The closest to conflict you'll find here is a some haggling over a repair bill, and even that is fairly good natured. But the real trick that Lynch pulls off is the warmth and honesty with which the story is told. Never for a moment does it descend into sentimentality, and it says quite clearly that not every problem has a solution. For fans of less-is-more film-making, this is for you. For everyone else, this is still for you. Unreservedly recommended.

reviews.review_title: A Beautiful And Extraordinary Road Movie
reviews.content: This film is pretty much perfect. It's hard to comprehend that this is actually a true story. The Straight Story is very slow paced, to it's credit. I just couldn't believe how slow Alvin's mower was when he started his journey, yet he was determined to go for 350 miles. The cinematography was beautiful with it's panoramic shots and pans. The acting was phenomenal and Richard Farnsworth should definitely win the oscar for his stunning portrayal of Alvin. He explored the themes of family and growing old so well, particularly in silence. He did the job so faultlessly that you could understand what was being said when nothing was being said. The score by Angelo Badalamenti contributed so much to the emotion of the story. I especially liked the 'road theme' which recurred throughout the film. David Lynch really is a master of his art form.

Since I see that other commenters have mentioned various scenes, I wish to compel those who collect sweet moments to watch this dear movie.  We all know that the most delicious moments in our lives, if we have the sense to savor them, are small and perfect. The first time I attended this movie I went for David Lynch's talents and was moved completely by the cinematography.The second time I saw the movie was to collect the sweet moments that the dear old guy in the film recognized and savored.  His road trip satisfied him down to his toes, every silly mile he putt putted down the highways.  His moments also included his ability to take stock of difficult memories of his past, and extract perfect understanding of the human condition.  I liked > his brief wise stories that left new enlightenment in each person he came in contact with.  They were told in a self-deprecating crusty way, as old guys (we hope) are wont to do, but everyone who had contact with him was somehow enriched. Words were spare, though, in this precious movie, and I'll see it again in a heartbeat if any theatres ever take a chance

I have long admired the work of David Lynch--"Eraserhead" and the original "Twin Peaks" TV movie being my favorites--and I expected from word of mouth that I would like "The Straight Story", but I was not expecting to be as touched as I was by this thoughtful, lovely work of cinematic art.  Perhaps I am simply at the right time and place in my life to appreciate the movie's messages (I can imagine some people, especially younger viewers, not having the patience for its leisurely pace and "plot"), but I feel privileged to have shared in a little of the journey (both literal and figurative) of Farnsworth and Lynch's Alvin Straight. One of the most resonant aspects of the movie for me was how it depicted the "American heartland" and its people and their very sturdy moral code (a major theme of "Fargo", also).  And it isn't a religious moral code either, though it does adhere to the basic Protestant tenet of "doing unto others as you would have them do unto you".  In this movie there is a definite sense of people wanting to do the right thing for themselves and for others--an all-for-one attitude.  This is, for my money, the type of movie that we of the spiritually-conflicted new millennium need right now, for it brings it all down to a basic level.  We need to take personal responsibility for ourselves and for others.  Alvin Straight knows what he needs to do for himself and his brother and it is a testament to his character that he lets nothing stand in the way of his doing it.  Alvin and all the others like him are the true heros of life. This story could have, in the hands of many other directors, been quite an intolerable affair (Rob Reiner? Steven Spielberg? Sorry to be insulting, but they would have laid it on thick!). Luckily Lynch was the one to do it, bringing both his keen, at times hokey (here appropriately so) sense of humor and his commitment to acknowledging life's "dark side" with him.  Yes, Lynch does Disney, but rather than leaving out the dark side, he simply subverts it (imagine a G-rated "Blue Velvet").  From the Olsen twins to the deer lady to that surreal star-dotted sky, things are, as usual, a bit off-kilter in Lynchland....and thankfully so! Final thoughts: It was really nice to have Sissy Spacek back in such an interesting (and, unfortunately, supporting) role. I'd like to thank David for that.  And as good as Kevin Spacey and Denzel Washington were in their Oscar-nominated performances last year, I'd have been thrilled to see Richard Farnsworth win the Best Actor award.  Now that this gem is out on video I look forward to seeing it again.  When you are in the mood for a such an experience, I urge you to do the same.

While watching this movie I was confused. I didn't understand why this guy felt he needed to ride his lawn mower the whole way to his brothers house. He spent over 300 dollars to get a new lawn mower, which would have been more than enough for a plane ticket. And he was offered a ride to his brothers house and turned it down. Which makes me wonder if he really cared for his brother or if he was just looking for publicity. It took him about 2 months to go see his brother who just had a stroke. This doesn't make sense to me. You would think he would want to see him as soon as he could. But other than this ridiculous story the movie is good. I said it is worth seeing because it shows you how stupid people are,  and how nice people are, the people he meets. It also shows you the power of silence. Don't expect anything from this and you might not be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: A most excellent and touching film!
reviews.content: I woke up this morning and turned my TV on.. This film was on. Never heard of it. After five minutes of watching, i knew i could not turn this movie off! I wanted to know what would happen to Alvin and Lyle! This movie almost made me drop a few tears, but i managed not to ;) It was so emotional and beautiful.. So full of love! Like, driving to another state on a lawn mower just to see your brother. The music was altso great. I like that kind of music! A little "Cold Mountain" stylish.. Well, this movie is a one of a kind one.. I think we all have something to learn from this! So.. Credit and respect to Alvin Straight!

This was a superb film that reveals the power that forgiveness can have within the soul of one human being (Alvin Straight).  Richard Farnsworth's performance was 10/10, and one could not have chosen a better actor for this role.  Sissy Spacek as Rose, the "slow" daughter of Alvin was also par excellence.  Thank you Mr Lynch, and company for such a wonderful and thought provoking movie.

reviews.review_title: can't believe what i am reading
reviews.content: I've read just about all of the recent comments and I'm shocked at how many people actually enjoyed this movie.  This movie was soooo boring I didn't even finish it, I just stopped caring.  Don't get me wrong, I love David Lynch movies and Twin Peaks rocked, the guy knows his stuff and the directing is definitely the only good aspect to the film, but the rest of the movie fails miserably to entertain, I think the story in general is quite interesting but I would rather of had someone just give me a two minute recap of the movie just so I know what happens in the end because basically myself and all of you people out there have probably had better adventures in our lives and better stories to tell than "please cheer for me" alvin straight, to comment on other people's comments, If I wanted a good look at nature for two hours I can just walk out my front door and go for a walk or watch the travel/naturel channel, if I wanted life lessons from an inspirational dying old man I could have read the excellentTuesday's With Morrie again in the same amount of time it took me to waste my time watching this film, if I wanted to watch a quality flick I could have rented anything else in the store and have been satisfied, and to the person who thought this movie would be better understood by an adult and had more moral lessons than American Beauty, what are you thinking, you obviously must have had no idea what American Beauty was trying to get at, it's strange because most of my friends who are adults hated American Beauty basically because they didn't get it either or they just didn't want to, if you catch my drift,

reviews.review_title: Forget the box office enjoy the quality
reviews.content: Any write up will tell you what this film is about, so I won't. It is a gentle and beautiful story without being sugar sweet. Don't go too deep into it, just enjoy the human interaction, the superb photography, the warmth of the storyline. Watch it when you have the time to relax or when you want to relax. And it is not just for soppy types. I love sex, violence, boxing, rugby and gory war movies but I loved this film too - because it is damn good. A beautiful snapshot of mid west America and her people which is well portrayed in this first class, well made film. If you any romance or sensitivity in you, I hope you will enjoy it as much as I did. See it.

David Lynch is one of my a-list directors, although Mulholland Dr. is the only one I have ever seen, when my interpretation told me what's it about,I was stunned , from time to time I'm awake in morning ,I know some thing appeared in my dream is what appeared in Mulholland Dr. ,it's awesome.The straight story is my second journey with David Lynch, a totally different experience , but the result is same , stunned.With several split-screens ,Lynch briefly tells the condition about the Straight and his living environment, which raise a question in my head then , how Lynch can weave a 2 hours movie after that? A long journey From Iowa to Mississippi , an old ill-man with his Mower? sounds boring.Alvin Straights' (Farnsworth) first attempt terminated due to the broken of the mower , but when he begins his second attempt, the story start hit me bit by bit , come across a wayward young girl who are running away and the Bundle of sticks fable , which may be a little cliché to me in other place , is now perfectly fit in this story , a nice family helped him when his Mower broke again after a dangerous drive , and the beautiful narrative of the WWII sniper story , lots of detail on the trip , just like a fantastic picture unfold bit by bit slowly , quietly , and emotionally , but the most beautiful part still left at the end of story , when his brother ask him when he saw the almost broken Mower ,'you just drive that thing long way to see me ?',My eyes has the same effect with Straights' brother , my heart was moved totally.In my Cultural desert nation, I'm proud to say that I still be capable of have some feeling in this movie ,and I have to thank David Lynch to let me know it

reviews.review_title: A lesson in directorial restraint and methodical lyricism
reviews.content: Richard Farnsworth gives a straight-ahead performance as Alvin Straight, 73 years old, grizzled, proud, stubborn, yet gentled by his long life. To describe Farnsworth's performance is to describe the movie itself: ruggedly golden, deliberately paced, methodical, focused, and deeply touching. Straight learns that his brother Lyle, with whom he hasn't spoken in 10 years, has been hit with a stroke, and after some thought determines to go see Lyle again. Hampered by bad eyes, Alvin cannot drive, and he is too proud and reticent to take a bus or receive a ride. His conclusion: to drive his old riding lawnmower to Lyle, more than 300 miles away in Mount Zion, Wisconsin. His journey takes a steady six weeks, and director David Lynch slowly paints his movie while Farnsworth slowly reveals Alvin's past, his family's history, his mistakes, his life philosophies.This movie never begs you to empathize, to shudder, to smile, or to sob; you cannot help yourself. Lynch has made a marvel: a movie that is undeniably human yet completely inoffensive. Like the simple rows of Iowa wheat, the steady lines of the combines, the pulsing whirr of the blades, "The Straight Story" slowly guides us to a bountiful harvest of forgiveness, humility, and love.

reviews.review_title: A Finely Made Film With One Fatal Flaw
reviews.content: I'm a big fan of David Lynch's, and my appreciation for his work seems to grow with each passing year.  I anxiously awaited the release of his newest film, "The Straight Story", after the long drought following his extraordinary but poorly received "Lost Highway".  My reward for this wait was a genuine film, with superb performances (though I admit to being moved more by Harry Dean Stanton's five minutes on screen than the admittedly wonderful Richard Farnsworth's previous two hours worth), lush photography (though after the fourth beauty pass over a wheat harvester, my beliefs about the Midwest were confirmed--God, what a dull place in which to live!), and another impeccable musical offering from Angelo Badalamenti.However, there is one fatal flaw in "The Straight Story" that prevents it from taking its place beside "Twin Peaks", "Twin Peaks: Fire Walk With Me", "Lost Highway", "Blue Velvet", "The Elephant Man", etc., as one of Lynch's finest moments--there is absolutely no dramatic conflict anywhere to be found in the film!  Any student of drama knows that in order for a drama to be compelling, there must be a dramatic conflict for the main character to go through, an obstacle to be overcome.  It could be argued that the dramatic conflict in the film stems from Alvin Straight's quandary of whether or not to reestablish contact with his estranged brother, but that question and resolution both occur within five minutes of each other. After that point, Alvin Straight never wavers from his decision.  Others might argue that the dramatic conflict lies in the precarious means by which Alvin chooses to reach his brother (the riding lawnmower he rides across two states).  Though this argument carries more water than the previous one, the two scenes wherein the lawnmower breaks down are played very low key (one of the times the lawnmower is replaced within three minutes of screen time--oh, the suspense!), with Alvin simply utilizing standard means (money and waiting) to get the machine repaired, then he's off for another ten minutes of beauty passes of wheat fields and paved roads.To make matters worse, we are never treated to the inner workings of Alvin's mind.  The traumatic history of the brothers is never delved into, nor are the actual personal battles of conscience Alvin must wrestle with on the way to meeting his brother.  Richard Farnsworth does an outstanding job of passing seventeen different emotions across Alvin's face in any given moment, but this does not entreat the viewer to the impetus behind those varied feelings.  This deprives the movie of both outer and inner conflict, rendering the movie well-crafted and performed, but almost completely lifeless and flat.  Having said all of this, I still think it's true that Lynch's worst outings are often more compelling and intricate than many directors' best, so please give THE STRAIGHT STORY two hours of your time. There are many gems to be found here.

reviews.review_title: A wonderful old man embarks upon a unique personal journey to visit his brother and to make amends for past conflicts between them.
reviews.content: I loved "Straight Story", though maybe you have to be older (or a David Lynch fan) to appreciate the subtlety in it.  It moves slowly along a mesmerizing path, and you find yourself on a kind of senior citizen yellow brick road observing one magic happening after another... all of which are presented with great subtlety and tongue in cheek humor. How wonderful it was to slowly be transported to a place where life's typical daily occurrences take on the same magic as Dorothy's trip to Oz!  Most of the audience lingered after the film was over as if they were loath to go back out into the frenzy of their own private lives.  Bravo, David Lynch!

I've just seen "The Straight Story" and i think it's a great movie, from a great director. The story is very involving and full of surprises and the movie goes by with the right times and the right pauses without anything being forced. By these times it's really a great antidote against Mission: Impossible 2.

This is a very gentle, nice family film. Yes, it is a little slow in spots and the new digital sound system (At least in the theater I was in) really does a bad job on dialog in three short scenes where the characters are far away and the sound of the dialog is very hard to hear, BUT the cinematography, the writing, the direction are all very pretty and crisp. If you are looking for a family film that all ages can attend, and a nice story where old and young co-mingle and learn from each other. THIS is the film to see. I applaud Disney for spending the money and making the time to make this very gentle and intelligent film.

A straightforward film from the man who gave us 'Lost Highway'. A very simple story about simple people who've lived their lives and who are -almost- ready to go. It may not seem very exciting, and to tell the truth, it isn't. But this film is nevertheless a must-see for every real movie-lover: the acting, the dialogue, and most of all the directing, make 'The Straight Story' one of the few films that I enjoyed thoroughly this year. Oh yeah, there are quite some pictures of highways in this film too...

I can't say this movie is the best Lynch has ever done because it has nothing to do with his other movies (and i love them so much!), but God what a masterpiece ! From the first image till the last one you get hypnotized by the beauty of the shots, of the music and especially of that old guy's soul. The look in his eyes, the stories of WW2, and his incredible stubbornness we all know...this man is everyone's grandfather, that's why he touches us so deep inside. David Lynch has been able to make us feel so peaceful and let us feel home for the first time.

reviews.review_title: A wonderfully warm, refreshingly honest movie
reviews.content: I'm not sure how anybody with a working soul could rate this movie any less than excellent.  Perhaps it doesn't have enough violence or wise-cracking idiotic cops involved in implausible chase scenes.  Maybe I was just influenced by the main character being a WWII vet, like my dad.  Their generation seemed to somehow grasp the importance of right and wrong, working for a living, family, values, and a strong sense of American brotherhood.  I enjoyed every second of this movie, the slow pace was necessary for the wisdom, goodness and honesty of the character to sink in to my baby boomer mind.  A man with determination, resolve and regrets making his way ever-so-slowly on the path to correction.  His last chance to make things right.  An interesting guy with lots of baggage but never complaining about it, on the contrary, only lets it out when he deems it could be helpful to someone who can't and maybe never will understand the complexities of life.  I saw the movie as a man that has been on the road all his life, knows he is coming close to the end, and needs to review and assess everything over the hum of a lawnmower.  A very good movie for people who should slow down, grasp life as it comes, and appreciate learning from those who have already travelled the path to wisdom.

reviews.review_title: Not a movie for intelligent people
reviews.content: I have seen many reviews for this movie, touting it as a great movie. I have my reservations. It appeals to a very limited audience to begin with. The movie is about an old timer from Iowa, Alvin Straight, who wants to visit his ailing brother in Wisconsin, so he decides to drive the 300 miles in a lawnmower. The apparent greatness of the movie is in the courage it takes an old man to actually undertake something like this, and the people he meets on the way and what he adds to their life. The unapparent foolishness (which most people seem to ignore) is that it takes him six weeks to make the journey! Alvin cant drive, and he doesn't like travelling by bus, so he would rather spend six weeks on a lawnmower at considerable risk to himself, rather than make a day long journey by bus! He also seems to forget the fact that his brother whom he so urgently wants to see to resolve some old dispute could very well die in those six weeks, rendering his 'courage' useless. A lot of people are touched by the conversations he has on the way with people, giving them parable like insights into life - so where was his wisdom when he needed to get himself on a bus and visit his brother - wasn't that more sensible courage? The movie is excruciatingly slow at times, and besides the fact that Alvin's story is not really worth telling, it could very well be told equally well with a lot of editing. I would not recommend this movie to most people - unless they're suffering from deep loneliness, psychological problems, unresolved issues, etc like the characters themselves.

I had to wait a long time before I could see this film. I'm a huge fan of David Lynch and the news that this film was very different from his earlier work made me very curious. Yet from scene one, I recognized the hand of Lynch. The opening sequence is very much similar to that of Blue Velvet and the pace in which the story is told reminds me of the relaxed pace of some Twin Peaks-episodes and e.g The Elephant Man. The dialogues are still absurdly compact. Richard Farnsworth and Sissy Spacek are very impressive and it was nice to see Everett McGill again. The end is brilliant. This is a movie which settles itself in your head and won't leave. I consider that a good thing.

reviews.review_title: This Was A Very Good Movie
reviews.content: Like they used to say, they don't make 'em like this anymore. This movie was very good, in the message it sent, and the job that Richard Farnsworth did. He deserved an Oscar. The only problem I had about it was the pacing. I never realized, after watching some of David Lynch's weird work, that he had so much patience. At times, the long shots of trees and clouds nearly made me lose interest. But Farnsworth's bright eyes, and great smile kept me interested all the way to the end. And the end was just perfect. We need more movies like this one today.

reviews.review_title: A subtle beauty you have to be open to
reviews.content: Some of the commenst like "Lost me in ten seconds". only highlight the subtle strength of this film. It's not for everyone, and even if it is for you, don't watch it with people who aren't into it. The nuances of the performances demand your attention. But you'll be rewarded with a experience that truly highlights the power of film. I live in the prairies up here in Canada. Those shots of combines harvesting, the rolling landscape, they hammer home again the sublte beauty of the landscape. Sure we don't have mountains but as you can see, rolling prairie has it's only thing about it. Oh and further to richard Farnsworth, I highly recommend his performace in the movie The Grey Fox. It's a Canadian classic and a true story about the train robber Billy Miner after he gets out of jail. Agian he is a man out of sync with the times and struggles. Great film as well. OOK eh? I'm done

Saw this movie a few weeks ago, and I loved it!  Being from Wisconsin, I remember reading about Mr. Straights' journey as he was taking it across the state.  The media portrayed him as kind of an eccentric, maybe a little crazy; but the movie did a much better job at letting us get to know him. Even though he had a minor role in the movie, the few minutes that we see Harry Dean Stanton are my favorites.  This is a great movie that I have highly recommended to everyone.

reviews.review_title: Mowing your own lawn is more entertaining!
reviews.content: Life is short. Don't waste two hours watching this mind- and butt-numbing paean to stubbornness and poor planning. Just because you're stupid enough to spend hundreds of dollars driving a lawnmower across Iowa doesn't mean you're a hero, no matter how much folksy greeting-card wisdom you dispense along the way. There is no character development at all from beginning to end. These are cardboard characters. I've had a crush on Sissy Spacek since Badlands (1973), but she was downright awful here. I could better imagine this piffle on the Hallmark channel (and it would still be near the bottom of the pile there).I wanted to like this movie. I really did. It came up as a NetFlix suggestion and I thought, "Oh yeah, I always meant to watch that." Roger Ebert gave it four stars. Well, from now on, I'm going to be more suspicious of the recommendations I get from both NetFlix and Ebert. (Gene Siskel, I miss you!)

I cried with a mixture of joy and sadness. One of the very best films that was ever made!I loved the little sounds, normal things, like putting away his things! THE ACTOR was very old, just like in the story. In Sweden we don't know of him, only David Lynch. I am going to buy the film. Somewhere, in Sweden no, maybe at Amazon?! So fantastic! The scene with the young and pregnant girl, wow! And: he knew how brothers are. That 20% of their working time goes to shouting at each other. The final scene, when he met his brother at last: no hugging and crying like women would have done. NO. They just greeted each other with nothing but... I cant describe it. But it was sentimental in a man's way of behaving...What happened after the film ended?I wonder what happened?

reviews.review_title: Atypical Lynch still at his best.
reviews.content:
It was impossible to watch this film without thinking of Richard Farnsworth's suicide in Oct 2000 (due to the pain of bone cancer). Farnsworth plays an aged & determined man who travels on his own terms to visit his brother who fell ill. A brother he hadn't spoken with since 10 years because of an alcohol induced argument.This is a film about the lifetime of human experiences. Its running themes include: the haunting & unforgiving nature of memory; simple reflections on living, loss & regret, and especially the strength of will & reconciliation.
Sissy Spacek is remarkable as Rose, Alvin's mentally challenged (?) daughter & impossible to ignore, especially in the scenes when she longingly looks out the window.David Lynch admirers might miss his usual focus on the unusual, however it's evident that he is, in fact, behind the camera. For eg, the way some of the scenes close completely & the next opens; the scenes with the ball rolling & how those were filmed; and especially Alvin's encounter with the distressed driver.A truly one of a kind film from beginning to beautiful end (`Yes I did'). Silence can say so many words.It will pull the heart strings of anyone who is able to feel the pulse of what it means to live & breathe.

Lovely filmm it took me away. The fact that nothing really happens but at the same time the film is never boring and I would even say it is fascinating :). The fact that this simple story could've really happened only makes it stronger. Besides my personal experience it is simply a refreshing film without all the abundant special effects, racing sports cars, millions of rounds of ammo... A must see!

reviews.review_title: A wonderful story! Do NOT miss it.
reviews.content: A David Lynch masterpiece. A wonderful story about dedication, drive, love, and the importance of Family and more. There is a scene where there is a example of The Family unit and that scene was used in one of our Church services. The Sermon revolved around that scene. A movie that needs to be watched and listened to. Richard Farnsworth was terminally ill during the filming and kudos to him for finishing this. I'd read later that his pain was severe during the majority of the filming. He left this Earth with this being some of his best work. God Bless You Mr. Farnsworth. We purchased the DVD of this movie. A true classic!

i loved this film!  i have been a david lynch fan since the beginning of time.  he has proven his versatility and originality time and again.  i don't think many directors could pull this off.  lynch is a director famous for dark subject matter, and now he brings us this wonderful, light hearted, possitive, family oriented kind of film.  film makers of the world, take notice!  you could learn alot from this man...

Do yourself a favor and schedule an hour and a half into your busy agenda to watch The Straight Story. With captivating simplicity, the movie tells the true story of an elderly Alvin Straight, who back in the 1990's, traveled over 250 miles to visit his ailing brother. Alvin's driver's license had been revoked because of his age and he wasn't about to let someone else drive him because of his stubbornness, so he sets out on his journey using his trusty lawn mower.I'd expect a movie featuring an elderly man to be full of Disney-style, heart-wrenching sympathy traps, but instead the story is genuine and straightforward, coupled with a refreshing message of principle and priority. It also has the best acting performances I've seen in a very, very long time and this only adds to the richness of the movie.So make sure you watch and listen to The Straight Story. It's a movie masterpiece about a journey we call life.

reviews.review_title: lost features due to cutting the film
reviews.content: "The Straight Story". Alvin starts his journey on an old faded red riding mower and then in an instant of time he is riding a much newer green/yellow John Deere rider. Why did they cut the time and place he switched machines????? A lot was lost to us purists. Is the DVD offered in an uncut version????? Why is so much notoriety given to Sissy Spacek when the only star of this wonderful story is Richard Farnsworth?????? It looks to me like they also cut the final scene. Why???? This is a wonderful rendition of a movie the like of which used to be offered when movies were the primary method of story telling. More movie making companies should use "The Straight Story" as a standard, no violence, no sex and acceptable language. Thank you for the privilege of commenting.
I've seen this several times I love it one of the best road movies I've seen.simple story but it captures people's emotions and interactions so well. I get emotional every time I watch it. Chas.

reviews.review_title: No gimmicks, no flash, no digital magic creating unreal worlds...
reviews.content: I could find no fault with this movie. I was transfixed. In my mind it was perfect. There are no gimmicks, no flash (except for a midwestern storm), no digitalmagic creating unreal worlds. This is the heartland at its best. David Lynch did this? Wow, will miracles never cease!The final scene said more with silence than an uninspired scriptwriter could say with a few hundred lines.

No snake skin jackets. No Black Lodge. No Michael J. Anderson. No Kyle MacLachlan. No Hollywood. No pencil-making factories. No underworld mob groups. No disfigured Englishmen. No angels under the radiator. No innocence lost. No sexual awakenings. No dectectives. No sci-fi spectaculars. No Julie Christie. No light/dark haired women. No identity swapping. No dream sequences. No "I have your disease in me now." Yes, maam, this is not your ordinary David Lynch movie. This time he just wants to sing a simple song......Or just tell the unusual true story of a 78-year-old man named Alvin Straight (the wonderful final performance of Richard Farnsworth) who drove his tractor through three states to see his dying brother (played by Harry Dean Stanton, the one wierd element in this film, besides the plot). Oh, Toto, I think we ARE in Kansas again...or Iowa, to be extact. The first time I saw this, I was flabergasted at the almost void of idiosynchcrasies. There are a couple of "party" references sprinkled throughout, if not just to remind the audience that we are actually seeing a film by THE David Lynch. This is David Lynch's first attempt at true story telling since "The Elephant Man," and maybe his best overall film since. While I still prefer the likes of "Mulholland Drive," I still think this is one of Lynch's best and sypathetic films to date. This also marks the first time the equally wonderful Sissy Spacek (who has worked with Lynch behind the scenes since "Eraserhead," and whose husband does Lynch's production designs) and her performance gives more from a "supporting" role than most films give from the leading ones. The Badalamenti music (see, this isn't such a departure for Lynch, afterall) is just gorgeous, even if it doesn't always complement the film at times. The photography is divine and the direction, as usual, couldn't be topped. The only concern is how many Lynch devotees will be bored while friviously waiting for the film to get "wierd." However, if you enjoy G-rated, Disney-released, Midwestern-set films, then you're in for a real treat! This is no space cruise (despite what the credits will have you believe), but it's worth the fare. A true family classic.

Its sunny roads immediately evoke the night rides of Lost Highway. These two different speeds, from two different movies of Lynch, share a common sensitivity that is hard to articulate in words. Perhaps in these hypnotic shots of the roads, the spatial movement, punctuated by a flux of discontinuous white stripes on continuous black asphalt, contains or points out the constancy and vibration of the determined soul. The camera, the psyche that is witnessing the change of time, the course of time. This is pure cinematic abstraction.It is in this way of thinking and experimenting with the duration of time, this movie sits very well with the rest of the Lynch's work: their essence can be summed up as trying to find the right tempo for the painting/scene at hand, giving it everything it deserves; extending it, creating two-three extra beats for the gravity of this second to sink in and stretch out, but also in order to distinguish this little hill-like moment, so that it can emerge, discontinuously, from the flattening series of moments, one after another, one linked with another, so that the 'overall' tempo of the movie does not dictates the tempo of the moment/second. The moment shines forth.In this search for tempos, the Straight Story beautifully demonstrates a spectrum of slow rhythms which are accentuated by the juxtaposition of other regular paces occupying the high road. It is close to the time of slow cultivation, to the earthly time without falling back on medieval cliches. Only by providing a rich texture of slownesses, the movie escapes the risk of reproducing the caricatures of old age and repetitiveness of the routine. Lynch is able to build up a wonderful temporal intensity: A determined character against the times, a figure of heart that cuts through space that insists on his existence and his will.Not just spatial tempo of moving with a small DIY car, but the perspective on moving on, carrying it on in the old age, another tempo which has to do with culmination, rest, remembrance and difficulty.As though with the old age time is filled 'afterness'. There is no more acceleration, but neither deceleration. In this star-like motionlessness, the old age shows the way to his companies. That distant time where memories become only realities.This is not the time as pure possibility, but time already-past, time as accumulated experience, time as wound and bond that grounds. Thus, the main character is truly an old star, moving next to that big Sun throughout the movie which is in fact Life. He moves, slowly but surely, without feeling any inferiority in the presence of Sun/Life, because he is a star and he knows the darkness in which a star shines (his own death) in the distance, he moves in his own place, in his own orbit.This is a journey movie, but as we move forward in space we move backward in time. Almost circularly, we return and move towards to the original decisions, original bonds as they determine our trajectory, as they already contain the end in themselves. We return to the beginning as though to repeat the unfolding sentence for the last time from the beginning to the end it this time, to conclude.

reviews.review_title: A 73 year old man decides to undertake a journey with a mower to resume the relationship with his brother.
reviews.content: The movie unfolds at a slow pace: music, colors, and dialogues are monotonous during the entire movie. Despite a relatively interesting opening, the level of genuine tension that motivates the spectator to continue watching the movie is extremely low. The idea of the director is to unveil a story of two brothers as far as the journey of the main character (one of the two brothers) develops but the degree of introspection is low and the gradual unfolding looses its meaning because it is very easy to detect the motives of the journey. Overall, the movie is characterized by redundancy: the spectator understands from the very beginning that the main character's life is sad but every few minutes, a melancholic music fades in, accompanying the narration of a depressing situation of the past. After the third narration, those among the most cynical spectators may start smiling instead of feeling empathy. I would not recommend this movie to those who appreciated Amores Perros, in the Name of the Father, and Diarios de una Motocicleta because they may be disappointed by the lack of rhythm.

Such a wonderful movie. The sense of devotion and community expressed in this picture made me understand a lot more about what is important in this life.And that people are on the whole good. I know it is slow, and I know it has a simple plot. It is not filled with clever allegory, but somehow it is one of the most beautiful and memorable movies I have ever seen. Thank you David Lynch, and thank you Richard Farnsworth, I have never seen an actor who can express such emotion and gravity by way of whiskers and mournful-wise eyes alone.Be patient, be calm, and go on Alvin's journey with him. Quite remarkable.

reviews.review_title: Incredible work by Lynch and Farnsworth
reviews.content: David Lynch's "The Straight Story" is certainly one of the finest films that I have had the honor to experience. Alvin Straight's journey from Iowa to Wisconsin, and the encounters with people along the way truly capture the human spirit. This is one of the most moving and peaceful films every created, and the score by Angelo Badalamenti definitely adds to the feeling. Farnsworth and Lynch should have won Oscars for this one. I recommend this movie to anyone who has the ability to truly enjoy films, regardless of genre or rating. David Lynch has shown that he can create gold from anything he touches, even if it is not your normal surreal, dark, Lynch film. "The Straight Story" is exactly the opposite. It is an absolutely touching film, that will leave you thinking about your relationship with family and friends. I recommend this movie to anyone who can truly enjoy films, regardless of genre or rating. Seek this one out and enjoy.10/10

reviews.review_title: " A road movie at 4 miles per hour"
reviews.content: I'll admit that when I first heard I was studying a movie about a man on a lawnmower I was a tad sceptical. However, after watching the movie all my scepticism had disappeared. Who'd have thought that such a slow paced movie could be so heart warming and enjoyable? Had I not been in a room full of fellow students (most of whom would have taken me to the cleaners) I would have shed many a tear. The ending was incredibly touching and although left a mystery, any other ending would have destroyed the film. I have never seen a film like it, nor do I believe I will see one again. I recommend it to anyone of any age. A true masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: Man rides mower cross country in real time (oops told the story)
reviews.content: I thought this was a joke played by a friend who told me to watch it.I kept waiting for something to happen.It is the worst piece of video (home movie) I have ever seen. I think it is done in Realtime.No editing.I was Very Surprised to see Sissy Spacek.It is actually very hard to write ten lines for this.that would tell you how the movie moves along. I had to mow my lawn twice while watching it.Very bad lighting, on the bright side it shows a couple nice sunrises. OK I am stretching it out nowIt is great if you need something to fall asleep to.wow..awful

I think, nearly everything has been said in the previous comments. So I only want to give some personal annotation about this beautiful movie.I started watching "The straight story" when I came home from a party. I was drunk and tired, but also curious about this one, because other Lynch-movies I saw gave me much to ponder.It started with this long and slow sliding of the camera through the garden of Alvin Straight, passing the fat woman dressed in pink, arriving at the rear window... And then...I fell asleep. I awoke several times while the movie went on. But every time I awoke the movie looked the same. Alvin Straight was slowly moving through America. Endless fields of wheat and corn surrounding him. To only get these snapshots accompanied by the fantastic soundtrack, while dozing, was quite surreal. The next day was a Sunday. And in the afternoon I watched this wonderful movie again. It was one of the best Sunday afternoons I had this year.

reviews.review_title: The green velvet of David Lynch
reviews.content: I don't know if anyone would ever expect a film of Lynch to be "straight" and "story".The amazing thing in this attempt is that he is using the lawn in a simple way and not as a passage (Blue Velvet etc.} to paranoia.The lawn is the base of the dramatical logic.And he achieves his aim!Including the help of a fabulous actor (Farnsworth) he is proving that the essence of his past (and future) directing shapes is a straight line and especially a line mowed by the third age!I don't know if the director will make again such a straight story.I'm not even sure if he will make again a "story".However,I know that this personal propitiation has been proved beneficial for the American cinema and for us!

reviews.review_title: But the story is fundamentally flawed
reviews.content: I saw this movie because of the high rating here. Everything else is fine, but the emotional story that the writer has 'tried' to build up just seems fake to me.If you ever need to go and visit a person who is on his death bed, then for the love of god, don't plan for days on buying a lawn mower, stocking food for the big 240 mile ride that's gonna take you weeks. Just be smart about it. Find a ride if you can't drive the car. I'm sure there are some real emotional people out there who would take you to your ailing brother.Maybe the pumped up emotions jive with a certain audience. I just couldn't stop thinking how silly the plot was throughout the movie.

I watched The Straight Story for the fifth time a couple of days ago and I swear, it gets better and better. More beautiful more emotional... I would watch it again if it hadn't just finished in the cinema in which I work. I'm not often moved greatly by movies but this one had my eyes filled with tears on numerous occasions. It also had me laughing out loud, truly exhilarated and immeasurably soothed. Richard Farnsworth has to get the Oscar for this because his performance is one of the most genuine and heartfelt that I have ever seen. Best Score should be snapped up by Angelo Badalamenti. Not that this film needs awards. It's quality speaks for itself. I advise anyone who has seen The Straight Story once and enjoyed it to see it again... and again and again! Truly one of the greatest Movies I have ever seen.

reviews.review_title: A relaxing and joyful movie experience
reviews.content: I can see why someone might view this film as slow- it certainly isn't a movie of this era. No big explosions or bizarre-o plot twists. But what this film does have is acting. Richard Farnsworth is a delight and can do more in a single frame than Kevin Spacey did with all of "American Beauty". No disrespect to Mr. Spacey of course, but this film easily demonstrates why Farnsworth was arguably more worthy of the oscar.you know the basics of this story by now, the lawnmower, the trip - I won't bore you with a recap. Just rent it and enjoy a real story.

reviews.review_title: very satisfying exception to violence and filth.
reviews.content: Beautifully acted and at times quite moving, lovely photography and very competent cinematography. The music is effective in setting the mood. The only disturbing element were the hordes of kids whose parents either did not check the contents first, or just assumed that a Disney movie must be for children, or could not afford a baby-sitter.

reviews.review_title: Richard Farnsworth will win the Oscar for Best Actor.
reviews.content: The fact that he was nominated over Jim Carrey tells me that it's Richard Farnsworth destiny to win the Oscar for Best Actor in 1999.  His acting in this film will win over the hearts and minds of the Academy members.  This was a truly memorable performance.

Simply, The Straight Story is a beautiful movie.  From David Lynch's magnificent cinematography to Alvin Straight to the wonderful characters he encounters on the road, The Straight Story conveys beauty in a way I have yet to see in a movie.  At its core, The Straight Story expresses a fondness for patience that is truly powerful.  Take the time to soak up the beautiful moments when they occur, take the time to remember the good things in life instead of focusing on the bad.  While certainly sentimental and optimistic, Lynch's willingness to find the good in people is powerful because it is so genuine.  And moreover, its refreshing.As a word of advice, some people may grow weary of scene after scene of Iowa landscape and little dialogue.  These people may find The Straight Story tedious and without beauty.  If you are simply unwilling to take the time to appreciate life's good offerings and lack the patience to bask in its beauty, then you will not enjoy this movie.  Perhaps that is the ultimate irony.

This is a great picture if you like to snooze in movie theatres.My impression was that it was made (ala Bob and Ray) bytheslowtalkersofAmerica.Hard to believe any of the rave comments about this flick.Don't waste your time or dough.

reviews.review_title: While mostly true to the facts, depictions of life in Iowa are not realistic
reviews.content: Growing up and currently living in Laurens, Iowa (the home of Alvin Straight) where it all began, and where a large portion of the movie was filmed, we rolled out the red carpet for the film crew and everyone they brought into our small town of 1,500. Though small, we are not living in the past as this movie highly portrays the "folks" of Laurens. If you think that we all were in the same mindset and living quarters of Alvin and his family, think again. The Straight house, better known as the stray cat house is by far the worst looking house in the town, in fact, if it wasn't for this movie, it would have been torn down just as any dilapidated house in Laurens is. We have several large manufacturing businesses in our town that do nation wide and international wide business. As for dogs running across main street, you won't find any as portrayed in the opening shot of the movie. We don't drive old beaters for car, yes, we too in small town Laurens own Cadillacs, SUVs, and other nice vehicles just as the rest of the world. We do have running water, cable TV, and the internet.
